We encourage you to have a look around the catalog first to see what we’re all about before posting your first thread. Topics typically posted here include:
>Outdoor recreational activities (Hiking, trail running, bushwhacking, camping, spelunking, geocaching, orienteering, expeditions, urban exploration, backpacking, etc.)
>Gardening, farming and related activities
>Hunting and fishing, and other activities involving the stalking or taking of game (including bird-watching)
>Outdoor survival, bushcraft, foraging, self-sustenance in nature, train-hopping, hoboism, etc.
>Outdoor destinations and exploration (specific trails, parks, regions, etc.)
>Water-related activities (boats, diving, etc.)
>Outdoor philosophy (conservation, Leave No Trace, protectionism, etc.)
>Outdoor building and living (cabins, huts, treehouses, etc.)
>Outdoor social activities and organizations (meet-ups, Scouts, NOLS, etc.)
>Gear related to any of the above topics

Most topics related to the outdoors are fine. Write properly, behave politely, encourage a respectful community, and most importantly, GO OUTSIDE!!

posts.com: There's a small pond near me that gets a fall trout stocking and it's cold enough through the winter that there may be some trout left in there. How should I go about catching them with spinning gear. How should I rig for powerboat or is there something else I should be trying?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: >>2533333

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533333
Fuck powerbait. Literally scented plastic paste. Cast marabou crappie jigs, small floating minnow style crankbaits, or inline spinners. Can also bobber fish with worms or fly fishing nymphs. Focus on getting the bait as close to the bottom as possible without snagging, if you aren't getting caught on the bottom once in awhile you aren't fishing deep enough. Look for deep holes, or areas where the current is broken up by large rocks or other structure.

That said, fishing in put-and-take heavily pressured trout fisheries is normally a waste of time outside of the month or so after they are stocked. They all get caught.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533355
Thanks bro, I'm more a salt fisherman but figured I'd give this a try since there isn't much active in the salt for the next month and I'm getting cabin fever.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533333
Depends on a lot of factors, such as the water temperature, actual size of the pond, how recently they were stocked, etc.

My experience with stocked trout cooped up in small pools and ponds is that you often have to try everything and the kitchen sink to get them to bite, and will be lucky if they actually do. I've fished pools so clear that I could watch every single trout and what it was doing. What they typically do is ignore (or turn to watch go by) every dry fly, wet fly, streamer, nymph, caddis, spinner, spoon, salmon egg, Trout Magnet, grub, worm, etc. Doesn't matter how thin the leader, whether or not a sinker and/or bobber are used, etc.

Whereas I can dip the tiniest Trout Magnet or a very tiny fly into a seam that I know contains a brookie, twitch it once, and then I have a brookie on the line. Brookies make sense: know where to go and where they'll likely be, avoid spooking them, ease a fly or plastic grub or something into their cone of vision, twitch, catch.

Best I can tell you with farm trout trapped in a barrel is to try everything. Probably live nightcrawlers would be best. My best theory is that farm trout mostly choose to starve while waiting around for trout chow. I've considered buying some trout chow and tying that on, but that hardly seems sporting.

Picrel, two of four stocked trout I caught out of a crystal-clear pool with my buddy last fall. We split them up. It took four hours to catch them using every conceivable technique, lure, and bait, and I don't remember which ones they randomly bit on because it all ran together after a while.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533361
I know they were stocked, by the way, for three reasons: there's no way they all got into that pool naturally at their size given the tiny rivulets feeding it, their skins look like shit (dead giveaway), and they were still in shock from being stocked, which is why they actually weren't biting.

Just happened to stumble upon them. Otherwise, Cletus or Jethro would have cleaned them out by the end of the day. Not a joke; rednecks began descending on the pool as we were leaving with our four. There were a few trout left.

And that's why I prefer backcountry fishing.

>>2533245
if you buy Yo-Zuri Hybrid just keep in mind that the diameter is thicker than mono per the rating. 6lb Hybrid is almost as thick as 10lb mono, and 4lb Hybrid is almost as thick as 8lb mono. Supposedly it breaks about 2lbs over the rating though, it's definitely not weak. it's not as limp as something like Trilene XL mono, but it's not bad at all. I still like Trilene XL overall, I've pulled some really bad snags that bent hooks with only 6lb and 8lb line, the stretch in that shit makes it break way above it's rating, and stretch isn't as big of a deal when fishing crankbaits or most hardbaits in general.

>I laugh at snobby fly anglers who act like stocked trout are easy to catch over a natural trout in the wild. It's so fucking hilarious. Everything you said is spot on. The hard part about getting a natural trout is finding and hiking to their location, also the funnest part IMO. But stocked trout can be finicky.
I'm primarily a fly fisherman of backcountry streams, and I do feel that the challenge of finding and not spooking wild trout is the more prestigious and interesting challenge. You do also need to know proper hook sizes, rigging, type and size of flies/lures/bait, and how to impart action to flies/lures. Once you do know these things, it's EZ PZ Nipponeesy.

It's true though that stocked trout aren't easy to catch; neither are stocked bass, although that's because they're so intensely pressured and we'll educated.

Stocked fish are usually placed where grandma on a mobility scooter can roll up and catch them. Jobless or retired people fishing then out all week while you work adds a whole extra layer of challenge.

posts.name: Anonymous

I exclusively use Antares's, Calcutta Conquests, and Metaniums. I recently picked up a Tatula 300 for my big, big swimbait rod and a tatula 200 for my 1-4 ounce topwater swimbait rod, they're kick ass reels man. For how inexpensive they are, they feel like tanks and are butter smooth. Only complaint (ONLY ONE) is that the drag star is obviously plastic, but that's a minor thing. Casts like a dream as well.

Cool thing about Tatula's is that their advertised spool size is actually much bigger to the comparable Shimano. Tatula 100 = Shimano ~180 spool, 200 = ~250-280 spool, 300 = ~350-380 spool. They hold a lot more line than the Curado equivalents, and that's cool. T-wing system actually works really well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534930
moderate/moderate-fast/fast/extra-fast varies from rod to rod, but generally it's just how far down the rod the bend is. slower = further down. think of it as a shock absorber. the only real downside is it takes longer to load up on hooksets(only really matters though if you're using retardedly thick gauge hooks.) Much more benefits, like better casting with less effort, and better at keeping a fish on the hook during the fight. Bass-centric fishermen will tell you to only get a fast rod, but they likely do 99% finesse fishing with ridiculously large hooks, which is simply unnecessary ways of the boomer. Crappie rods for example have slower actions, so that the fragile lip of the fish doesn't tear during the fight, yet they have to rely on very sensitive strikes, so that proves the concept that you don't need a fast action for most stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533594
>when to start seedlings
that is entirely dependent on your latitude and topography. if you're getting enough sun, and you can heat the greenhouse, go for it. But think of it like this, the point of a greenhouse is to extend your growing season by letting you start before the last frost, and continue past the first frost. But the absolute dates for those events are location dependent. Depending on your setup (heating, grow lights) you can grow year round if you wish.

i'd post a picture of mine, but it's still under construction, and it looks like it was made by orcs -- as I am not a carpenter. but basically it's 8x12 with suntuff panels on the southern wall and on the single slope roof. EWN sides are 3/4 plywood. there wasn't much sense in spending the money on clear panels for sides that will never see direct sun (not to mention heating/cooling costs that would impact. The exterior is 'finished' (minus trim); on the interior i need to finish the walls and paint. (doing plywood vs drywall because of the humidity)

But to answer your question: I'm in western oregon at ~1100 ft of elevation, we're surrounded on 3 sides by trees and have a butte to our south which blocks out low sun early in the day during fall/winter. I'll be starting my peppers and tomatoes by mid month.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535024

Training commands with positive reinforcement is best of course. I'm not suggesting putting an e-collar on your dog and zapping it until it comes to you out of confusion and anxiety. Quality modern e-collars have precisely adjustable stim levels, usually something like 0 - 100, with most dogs starting to notice the sensation around 5 - 10. This means you can use very low levels just to get their attention, like reaching out and touching them, and high levels when all else fails and they're about to run into traffic or something.

It's possible to get near perfect recall with positive reinforcement only, but an e-collar is the only way to be sure you are always in control of your off leash dog.

>>2534999
>Hey that's the brand which some anon from here bought, loaded up, picked the bag up "incorrectly" and the entire strap tore off.
Nope. I remember making fun of that guy for not knowing how to use the hoist handle. It was a Hyperlite Mountain Gear pack.

It looks like you're also too much of a dumb tourist to know what the hoist handle is for. If you load a bag to at or near its stated weight capacity, grab it by one hauling strap, and fling it around like a retarded gorilla, the strap might rip free, or it might not; but it will weaken the stitching and increase the odds of it breaking in the future.

So yes, whirling your pack around by one hauling strap when it is full is "incorrect." The straps are rated to carry the max load (plus safety margin) while they are both on your shoulders. You use the hoist handle to carefully pull the bag up and put it on when it's full.

It's all right, I'm not judging you for being an ignorant retard who can't use a pack properly, doesn't know how to read a map, is a LARPing suburbanoid, etc.

>>2525716
>>2525743
Ankle support Is sort of a catch 22. It's the stiff sole and elevated heel that fuck up your natural mobility and stability, so you need ankle support to compensate when walking in rough terrain, because you're on an elevated stiff platform and heel striking, which is the actual problem. You land on the heel, your calves are not engaged to support propert and you twist your ankle before you have time to react.

A stiff sole is pretty much only needed for climbing, mountaineering and using crampons.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Unlike conventional hiking boots that have extremely built-up soles and elevated heels, minimalist shoes possess almost no variation in sole height from heel to toe as well as a relatively thin sole. Because your foot is closer to the ground, it’s less likely to roll. In physics terms, the moment arm in minimalist shoes is extremely small or almost nonexistent, which is not true of conventional shoes, including most running shoes and hiking boots. A moment arm is the perpendicular distance from the point of rotation to the line of action of a force, and the moment is the tendency of the force to cause rotation (i.e., ankle rolling) about an imaginary axis through a point.

>Most conventional shoes and hiking boots possess tapering toe boxes that force your toes into a wedge position, causing toe deformities and misalignment and other problems over time. This toe wedging is a true problem, as it strips your foot of its inherent ability to protect you from ankle rolls. When your toes are positioned or aligned the way nature intended, and when your foot is allowed to sit on a level plane, you create a stable base of support—a tripod, essentially—that naturally resists ankle rolling.

>something thatll last you a lifetime

Doesn't exist. Either you get an EVA midsole that compresses after a couple 100 miles, a PU midsole that hydrolyses after a couple years or a leather midsole that will torture your feet on long hikes. Even if you can resolve the latter, eventually the upper will wear out. Historically, footwear has always been a consumable. The idea of a boot that will last you a lifetime is nothing but a sales pitch. Get something that fits your feet and your purpose. Sometimes that means stiff-soled GTX-lined mountaineering boots, sometimes that means lightweight breathable trail runners.

>Ankle support Is sort of a catch 22. It's the stiff sole and elevated heel that fuck up your natural mobility and stability, so you need ankle support to compensate when walking in rough terrain, because you're on an elevated stiff platform and heel striking, which is the actual problem. You land on the heel, your calves are not engaged to support propert and you twist your ankle before you have time to react.

>A stiff sole is pretty much only needed for climbing, mountaineering and using crampons.

Holy shit, another anon who actually gets it. A few months back I was ranting in one of these footwear threads about how the Aztec pochteca walked barefoot to trade their goods, the Native Americans wore moccasins, and the Roman legions wore sandals (tall, heavy, hobnailed sandals, but sandals nonetheless).

"I bet they'd have worn boots if they'd had them," was the brainlet response.

No, they'd have gone on being shod with flexible soles, because unless you have the squishy feet of an obese air conditioning-sitting office faggot, flexible soles are superior by far for rocky, uneven terrain.

But no doubt we will continue to hear about how you have to wear boots for ankle support, even though the stiff planks that pass for soles on those things contribute much more to injury than ankle support ameliorates.

There's a time and place for boots: When you absolutely need them. I have five pairs: knee-high muck boots, mukluks, duck boots, work boots, wading boots. But I wear wimpy, light, flexy things whenever I can get away with it.

Picrel, literal Inuits each with far superior survival skills to anyone on this board, not actually wearing boots but rather sealskin moccasins. Get fucked, fat retards.

>>2520224
I grew up in a village in germany. Germany is a pretty urban country, and as a result most forests are pretty "tamed". But it was plenty in the eyes of us kids.
Our main motivations were that it was essentially a big playground without supervision. No parents, no strangers, just us. It was possible to play in many ways (play with softair rifles, or dig trenches, or build treehouses, or shelters) that you simply didn't have the space for at home. The biggest draw was the feeling of adventure. We'd climb under the electric fence where sheep were held and pet them (sometimes they'd let us sometimes they'd attack us), then again under it back into the forest, we'd sometimes "steal" honey from some beeskeeper (he knew, but he also knew we wouldn't take much, so he let it happen), we'd search for treasure, go in places that were forbidden (a old mine and a forest bunker were favorites) and sometimes we'd go looking for animals. Always hoping to see deer or a hog, but usually having to settle for some frogs or squirrels instead.
>And also what was the best thing or THINGS you did there?
I have the fondest memories of building shelters. We had "bases" in the forest and inside those we stashed our treasure - stuff we had found. The coolest among those were WW2 leftovers, we had found a ammo box, something that may have been artillery or a mortar round, thankfully not live, and a lot of animal bones. Other than that, fighting with sticks, exploring the mine and the occasional hog encounter.
>>2520359
>at what age would it be safe to turn your kid loose to go play in the woods?
Once they can be trusted to know their boundaries and the risk of the forest around them. It really depends on the forest though. I'd say we were "fake alone" by something like 6 (as in thinking we were alone when parents actually watched/were nearby in emergencies) and really alone around 8.

that's the thing though, those close calls we have as kids are actually extremely formative; the tendency towards safety mommyism might actually do more harm than good. i guess it's finding the right balance and praying nothing too catastrophic happens.

where i grew up, we'd often play in the river (hunting snakes/crawdads in the summer). There was a bridge just outside of town with a small dam and sluice box; if the water was high enough we'd jump into the river from the bridge (maybe a 30' fall). Well one summer some kids were jumping off it, but the sluice box was left open. Two kids got sucked in, one drowned and the other became a vegetable for the rest of his life (wound up drowning on his own saliva at the hospital a few years later ironically enough). I think back on how lucky I was to not have that happen. As a parent I wouldn't let my kid jump off that bridge, all the while knowing that my childhood summers would have been worse for such concerns =/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520477
>the tendency towards safety mommyism might actually do more harm than good
I 100% agree with you. Some freedom, and that includes the freedom to fuck up, is needed for kids to become adults. But some risk is also unneeded. Getting hurt playing in the woods and either fixing it with friends together or going back home injured is formative, hitting the rusted WW2 artillery shell with a stone to see what's inside may have ended badly.
I still remember the very first time I went somewhere alone:
I was very young and my parents allowed me to get bread from the bakery alone on a sunday. It involved walking down 3 streets, crossing a small intersection, going into the store, ordering, paying and going back. I couldn't do math yet, so I had no idea how much I had paid or gotten back, but I remember how proud I was when I got back home. Years later I found out I never was alone - my father had followed me with a camera to see if I would cross the intersection carefully, avoid any traffic and be alright on my own. Once he knew I was fine, he knew I could be trusted to leave the house alone from there on.
I think the way they did it was best: First a pilot run, where they kept me safe but I could feel like I was alone. Then once that went well, they let me do my thing. That way they could trust I was fine on my own and I could be free of parental control.
Your main goal is avoiding the shit that can result in death or severe injury, for the rest, it's better if they find out themselves.
We had plenty a injury from homemade fireworks, fighting with sticks, etc. Kids learn surprisingly quickly to take care of each other.
Either way, don't stress about it too much anon, you sound like a great parent. Listen to your inner fears, then rationalize how probable they are. If they are unlikely, allow your kids freedom. If it's reasonable, air on the side of caution. You got this.

>>2520224
I grew up by a forest. I think I walked every path every day every summer from when I was old enough to walk until I had a job in high school.

It was nice. The quiet lets you collect your thoughts, feels good to breathe the air, it was calm with the exception of the occasional other kid or family hiking through.
>the park was preserved by the city, so it didn't shrink, but there's a highway on the north side, high-density housing on the east, and ever increasing intensification on the remaining sides, so it's no longer quiet
It was fun to tell jokes, or stories, or just look for critters. There used to be a lot of raccoons and bats there, but now there's not a lot. Sometimes we'd build little teepees or shelters. But the park staff would yell at us if we got caught, although I suppose there was no real repercussions.
>I walked my parents' dog through the forest a few months ago
>some kids had built a lean-to and were shooting some kind of drug
>I phoned the park building, they seemed annoyed I had bothered

The forest has a lot of hills. If you're not paying attention you can just step off and fall down a 45+ degree incline until a tree stopped you. Well over a decade ago, I remember some friends and I were screwing around, probably just telling jokes and being useless like usual, when one of us tripped and fell down the biggest hill the in the forest. He was just covered in bruises the next day, probably hit every single root and stone on his way down.

Nothing really happened there that was "the best," but I remember loving my walks with my dad. No real events, just wasting time with dad and trying to catch fireflies in the park on the far side of the forest where it opened into a field. Maybe the druggies and dirtbags were always there, but I only remember him explaining things like the pine trees leaking pitch because of the beetles, daring me to climb the trees that mum never would let me, lying to me about how fast a runner I was, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: How long could you last innawoods if society collapsed whilst you were camping?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525955
best almost everywhere: merino wool nylon blend
best in hot+humid weather (florida etc): thin coolmax synthetic
really fucking rainy places (pnw etc): thick coolmax synthetic

avoid 100% wool imo. the lifespan is too short and its wasteful. when you blow holes in 100% wool socks they're done for, whereas with nylon blend ones you'll still have the nylon mesh the wool's attached to in tact to hike out on until you can replace them.
consider stronger mixed natural fiber blend socks if you're one of the anons who doesn't like synthetic fibers and want to fully avoid them.
wool alternatives: alpaca (hypoallergenic, non itchy, bit less durable) bison down (more durable + better thermal properties) muskox (similar durability, best thermal properties) and angora (best-best thermal properties but can only be blended in small %s because fiber is very short)

posts.com:
>>2525955

posts.name: Umbrellanon
posts.com:
>>2527985
My man!

Short answer: yes.

But! Umbrellas are very situationally dependent. Sometimes they’re absolutely the best option, and sometimes there are better options out there. If there’s a lot of wind driven rain (and I mean a lot, not just a slight breeze in a light drizzle), you might be better off with a jacket. If the trail is really over grown (basically bushwhacking; a little overgrowth won’t hurt anything), then your umbrella may get snagged too often.

Where they work well is light to moderate rain. Just as a rain jacket is paired with pants, an umbrella can do the same. They also pair well with a very light jacket, such as a water resistant running jacket. That combo provides heavy protection from rain via the umbrella while the jacket keeps any blowback from soaking you, and it’s still more breathable than most options. A lot of thruhikers are using this combo now. It’s pretty versatile; if it’s not raining too hard you leave the jacket off and use just the umbrella (unlike just a rain jacket, where it’s all or nothing).

Breathability is a huge umbrella advantage. It’s why it’s the absolute best rain protection in hot environments during rainy summers. In the South, rain showers spring up out of nowhere, and dissipate just as quickly. They’re so scattered that raining while the sun is out is fairly common. A jacket would leave you very hot and sweaty.

Is it still /out/ if I can get food and shelter from convincing strangers to let me sleep in their house and eat their food for a night?
It's still be doing 25+ Mile hikes through wilderness by compass through whatever nature throws at me but when there's so much private property and available food it feels as though doing otherwise is trying to maintain a dead tradition rather than focus on what's really important like going out and touching grass.
The historical document the Red book of Westmarch recovered by anthropologist and philology Professor John Ronald Reuel Tolkien depicts a story where people thousands of years ago walked like 2,000 miles (some barefoot, one morbidly obese, another very old) and it was nearly all through nature but the people still stayed at people's houses and ate people's food along the way. That historical account feels more real than the self imposed survivalism stuff I see a lot here.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2531024
>Is it still /out/ if I can get food and shelter from convincing strangers to let me sleep in their house and eat their food for a night?
It doesn't have to be a months-long expedition to qualify as /out/. Even day hikes qualify as /out/. The conflicts on /out/ arise when casuals start to delude themselves that they're more experienced than they really are, that the scope of what they do outdoors is wider than it really is, or that they're experts in some aspect of outdoorsmanship when they clearly aren't.

The vast majority of arguing on /out/ is between a bunch of casuals, none of whom are experts. It's obvious and it's why I love the board, pure entertainment. That said, experts often disagree with each other as well.

"Trail angel" is a common term for people who help out hikers, up to and including providing a meal, shower, and possibly a bed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: What are some ways I can attempt to predict the weather conditions for the next hour or two just by my eyes?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533248
How far can you see? If you're in a steep sided valley you won't see the thunderstorm until it's on top of you. But generally, high cirrus clouds indicate good weather. Birds will head for the nest as bad weather approaches. Sudden cold wind in the summer means a cold storm approaching.

The best you can do is to learn the climate of the area you're in. For instance, the Rockies typically get a thunderstorm in the afternoon during June and July. Don't tempt fate by going out woefully unprepared. Get in the habit of looking up and around for approaching storms. If you head out on a perfectly clear morning and start seeing clouds in the middle of the day, that's your clue that a storm might be coming. If you're below treeline you might not care too much but it's always good to keep an eye peeled.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533125
If you're not hiking far look into arborist gear bags or bags for climbing big walls. My brother (an arborist) has a Weaver gear bag that will last a thousand years but it's not comfortable at all. It's essentially a duffel with shoulder straps. A small wall bag like the Metolius Sentinal might be more comfy because it has padding and a hip belt. I have a Gregory Baltoro that is super comfy for heavy loads and burly for a backpack but I'd pad any tools before loading them in. Maybe check out the Gregory Stout 45, it looks about the right size.

I worked on a trail crew for a few years and I carried all my personal gear and a chainsaw in, or strapped to, an old Kelty frame pack. 35 to 50 pounds of tools, water, clothing, food and first aid up and down mountains was pretty easy back then.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534419
>Do trekking poles lower energy expenditure? started to see younger folks using them and trying to figure out why
They're basically useless for anyone under the age of 60, with the exception of mountaineers at very high elevations. In high-altitude conditions, your oxygen-starved body simply doesn't work the way it should, even after acclimation, and of course you're ascending or descending relatively steep slopes.

For everyone else, they're a stupid trend. Photos and videos of mountaineering have always existed, but really exploded in the 2010s after GoPros, selfie sticks, and monetized YouTube really took off; famous sponsored mountaineers such as David Lama even started bringing camera crews with them.

Tourists and day hikers saw all these professional mountaineers using trekking poles, wanted to be just as cool (heh) as they looked, so now every last zoomer and yuppie uses the damn things, and in recent years gear manufacturers have been making tourist-grade packs with trekking pole storage loops, tarps meant for trekking poles, etc. (These tarps aren't for mountaineers, you know, due to the fact that gale-force winds will rape a tarp straight off the face of a mountain).

They even imagine that the trekking poles help them hike/ascend better, will swear by it, but this is a placebo effect slash justification for their mountaineer LARP.

They're more like lines, series of parallel lines, and intersecting lines in seemingly random places on his body. Historians think these may have been medical charms meant to prevent pain or induce healing, because he had these tattoos on top of old wounds and over his bad back.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2530289
Bayous in Louisiana aren’t stagnant. Not sure if that matters in the definition. Colloquially the words bayou and swamp are used interchangeably, and sometimes man made water ways are referred to as bayous (but never as swamps). The same goes for wetland and marsh; I don’t know if there’s a technical difference, but we use the words interchangeably. Generally “wetlands” is used in a broader scope, like “save the wetlands”, while marsh is more specific; “my hunting camp is surrounded by marsh.”

Anyway, Louisiana’s bayous, swamps, marshes, and wetlands are terrible and never any fun. Don’t come here, ever. Trust me, it’s bad.

>>2533005
It's not a polygon based map, it's just centroids based on named locations using the selected keywords.
Since Minnesota has fewer uniquely named wetlands that are larger in size, it gives the false impression that there are barely any wetlands in Minnesota.
It's interesting that Wisconsin and Michigan apparently have multiple named bayous though.
Also interesting that Texas and New Mexico don't have any named coulees even though there are absolutely plenty of features that fit the description, but those states weren't historically settled by French-speaking populations so they are called otherwise.

>Broad brimmed hat
>Fly net that goes over the hat
>Leather "Riggers" gloves
>Multi-tool with pliers and a serrated blade
>Sunglasses that aren't shit
>Bulk SPF50+ sunscreen

>Wireless earbuds or headphones

posts.com:
>>2530284
forced patina is what you want, like anon said.
and like anon said all you have to do is expose the knife to something acidic for a while.
how i personally prefer to do the acid etching depends on how i plan to use the knife. really thick patinas last a long time between re-applications but give the metal a sort of matte texture which drags on food.
knives that might contact food: i just stab a banana or apple or something and leave it for a day.
knives that will not contact food: near-boiling apple cider vinegar for a few mins, or cold apple cider vinegar overnight. cheap household product you might have around already that gives near-black super thick patinas that last forever. the patina sheds a bit at first but it goes away, rub it down real good.
people make it more complicated than it is that's all you really need to know.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
the exact materials i used as examples can be swapped out for anything with vaguely the same ph.
and if you do a thick ass patina then decide you want to use the knife to process food, the matte texture etched into the metal eventually wears off its not permanent.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2530494
>Even the sheath is good for just hanging off whatever your wearing.
>mora sheath
everyone either loves or hates the modern mora sheaths. they're really polarizing for a sheath.
the little plastic tab hanging off of it is meant so that you can daisy chain multiple knives to each other. its actually a really cool idea/feature but if you don't ever plan on using it the sheath can be significantly improved by grinding or cutting it off the sheath because it really likes to catch on clothes.
the classic mora sheaths are DOODY BUTT ASS. they're trash but that was always the case with classic moras.

i think even if you hate the mora sheath like some people, its super worth it to get a custom kydex or leather sheath made for one. seems silly to spend $30-50 on a $10-20 knife but if you think about it, its still an incredibly competitive knife at $50-70 and once you buy the sheath you can replace the knife that goes in it unlimited times forever for pennies if you ever lose or fuck it up.
i cant think of any better beater knife than a mora with a custom sheath desu.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here I will post outdoors pictures I took from my life in France and comment on them

A limestone quarry in Creil, northern France. Probably from the 18-19th century. Old newspapers from the 90's were thrown away there

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Forêt de chantilly in northern France, around the castle of Chantilly, not far from Paris
Many ticks in the foilage, as deer inhabit these woods and are still hunted with hunting dogs the old fashioned way

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
La sèvre Nantaise river in Northwestern France. Its a slightly deep valley surrounded by wineyards and pastures. Muscadet wine is produced there.
Its an oceanic climate which can only be found in western europe and New zealand, although NZ is noticeably warmer and UK is is colder

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: La Somme region in northern France, named After the river Somme which has been turned into a canal. Today people bike alongside it and can visit WW1 memorials in this very rural region.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A forest of spruce trees in the Jura region, a mountaineous region in eastern France.
The main mountain ranges in France are all located in the east and are as follow, from north to south : Ardennes (shared with belgium), Vosges (part of the same forest as the black forest in Germany), Jura, Savoie, Haute-Savoie, Écrins, Vanoise, Mercantour
The highest mountains of France are in haute Savoie so the Jura is relatively low in altitude, summits mostly reaching 2000m altitude at most

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Jura still

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Mercantour mountain range, the closest to the mediteranean sea, thus it has med influences. The summits are round and dry and the grass is all burnt up during summer. Its also the only place in France where you can find larches.
The first sightings of the return of the wolf in France in the 90's were made there
Pastoralism is still a strong tradition in this wild area

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: More of Mercantour

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Around Nice, on the coast of the mediteranean sea, altitude is lower so it is much warmer
Many streams flow down the hills into glens, where the shadow and humidity allow for different plants to grow into a little jungle

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: These glens can get flooded during heavy rains. You can also find dead animals, and wrecks of cars, and many other strange items. Spiders like to place their webs above the streams

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Back to Mercantour. It is so wild, hikkers regularly disappear, and they are never found out again.
Carrion birds can take care of carcasses really fast. Better not venture out from the tracks

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Cows and wolves have to share the same forests

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In mediteranean France, you cant hide from the sun. During summer, it can get to 35 degrees celsius pretty quick.
It smells of olive trees, pine needles, and you can hear the cicadas

There used to be many water mills, but now theyre all ruins

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Compiègne forest in northern France. There arent many "wild" forest in France anymore : since antiquity, they have been reworked into optimal wood production and circulation for the royal hunts
Even then, theyre nice to walk around.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The Alabaster Coast is in Normandy. Tall cliffs of white chalk dominate the sea. Not far from D-day sand beaches. Normandy is also know for its apples, cider and dairy products (camembert, cream, milk)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Chalk and limestone is everywhere in northern France

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: A forest in the Ardennes. French Ardennes are not "wild" per se since they have been used for woods, but theyre quite desertic. You can go for days without seeing anybody. Just praise you dont get shot by a drunk hunter.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: La sèvre Nantaise river again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In the 50's, the water was safe for safe for consumption and swimming, but chemicals products used in the agricultural corps above the valley have made it unsafe

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Back in northern France, where everything is flat and nature is heavily domesticated. Potato and beet fields everywhere, and the rivers are turned into canals for the boats to reach Paris and Belgium.
This is where I walked 60km for the first time since its all flat

And thats it for today, have a good read anons

posts.com:
>>2528058
Looks like the southeastern alps ?

Pyrénées is the southwestern mountain range, its very wild and has bears, on the borders of spain. Pilgrims cross that mountain range to reach saint jacques de Compostelle.

In Northwestern France you have Britanny which has celtic heritage, climate akin to UK, cliffs above the ocean, islands, and rivers flowing deep into valleys in the countryside, such as scorff river (picrel) or léguer river. Outside of summer you wont meet many people except fishermen.

The countryside of Nantes also has the Maine river and Sèvre Nantaise river end Erdre river and Loire river which are beautiful.

Emphasis on rivers because Northwestern France is flat so theres a lot of agricultural fields and few forests

If you want to do a GR, use gr-infos.com.

>>2534825
To walk though most of those parks you'd need days, if not more in the mountains. France has fairly low population density around Massif Central, but most places are fairly rural outside of big cities besides there. Just because a place isn't marked officially as a park or reserve it doesn't mean you can't go /out/ there. France is probably the best EU state for /out/ considering how much variety there is for climates and how many different mountain ranges you can get. Plus if you want to become a homesteader private property out in very rural areas is cheap, but most people don't want to live out in middle of nowhere with a bunch of chickens and very reserved countryside people as neighbors.

Okay I'll bite.
First things first Outdoors where? The tropics are not the frostline the tundra is not the swamp and the city is not for straight people.

Do not buy things. Take a long time to figure out what you need to learn first. You can approach this two ways. Watch youtube cringe, get bad advice here (my favourite) and finally you can try to connect with eople who do stuff outdoors.
Here's what I think is important to cover.

1
Get a good pair of boots that fit a nice pair of socks. No matter what you do you will always be able to use them, even if you don't wind up being outdoors oriented. Try on a bunch and make sure they are just a little bit bigger than usual and fit your foot type.

2
Next you want a bag. No less than 45 litres, no more than 65. Avoid Osprey cringe and old ass milsurp.(pre 90s unless you want to try a heavy alice pack for fun) Get cheap decathelon or REI's deals on a sale. You want something that you can ft water bottles in the side, that has a good hip belt.

3
Sleeping bag.
The more you spend on this the warmer and lighter you can get it. You can try for a normal synthetic fill. Maybe Snugpack would be a cheap option that has plenty of non expensive options in a temperature range that matches your area. Always get the warmest you can.

For shelter get a tarp. It's cheap and cheap aluminium pegs are great. With some cord you can figure out the ins and outs of using a 3x3 tarp to stay sheltered almost anywhere. If you chose to get a hammock you can keep using it for a fly.

Boots, bag, sleeping and shelter covered now you can start on skill specific equipment.
Get a plain flat backed knife. Full tang if you have money for a good one, or a mora if you are cheap and want a beater that works. This will be your learning toolset.

With that decided, you should have considered where you will go, what kind of conditions for weather you will be facing. The temperature. The use of fire.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529825
Next thing is food. Try not to pack cans. They are heavy adn will be annoying. For the first night you can always take fresh food. Don't worry about freeze dried or shelf stable unless you are doing long hikes or a couple of nights. That's on you, decide if you just want to do overnight or just get used to walking with your gear. You should wear boots a while to get them broken in, pack your bag and do some long walks with it packed. Condition yourself. It helps.

The thing to do next is to get a habit of reading. Find some outdoors lit and make a point of digesting it. Every skill that you have will rely on practice, but practice is always enhanced by reading. It will help you get an idea of what is considered normal or conventional knowladge.
For you I would reccomend The DK Survival Guide AKA The Royal Marines Survival Handbook in some nations. It is one of the best composed and illustrated books on all the basics that I've ever seen. Nothing in that book that you should not know. It's all sensible. So try that out.
There is a difference between homesteading, thru hiking (annoying faggot magnet) and the slow arduous habit of learning how to hunt or do expeditionary trails with no suppourt. Whatever you chose to do, get a group. Make freinds. Find others who will show you how to shoot and go out of your way to learn something every day.

How would anyone know what happens to Dyneema after 20 years? It hasn’t even been around that long, let alone common place.
When PU coated fabrics first became a thing, they peeled much quicker than 5-6 years, sometimes only in a matter of months.
New materials advance and improve, and Dyneema since switched to a different type of Mylar than what was used in many of the early shelters that had issues with delaminating.
Many problems with it tend to be related to shelter or pack construction, such as poor choice in seam construction, too short a stitch length, or not reinforcing properly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526131
>it's the fiber itself that deteriorates.
And what is the mechanism that deteriorates the UHMWPE fibers according to you?
Early Cuban fiber stuff delaminated in a way that the mylar separated at the stitching due improper stitch choice and reinforcement of the area.
It also had problems with sagging on doors early on, due to the type of Mylar used not bonding as well with the adhesive used, and being non-woven it allowed stretching along the bias.
Both of these problems have been remedied by shelter and pack manufacturers updating how things are constructed, and DSM switching from M to K type mylar for better adhesion and less brittle

I also met trailrunners that could only do 25 miles a day with their 15lbs packs. There is just a lot of human potential when it comes to traversing long distances believe it or not.

Are you in the UK? Hostel option I mentioned is a good workaround from being completely homeless. Work is usually easy and involves sitting around a lot. There's loads of opportunities to get laid if you're decent looking and can LARP as some cool traveller guy. Just don't make it obvious you're a bum, most hostels don't want anything to do with that sort as they're largely scumbags and retards. You get a place to stay without needing contracts, deposits or any other nonsense. In UK you can definitely use a letter from hostel manager as proof of address... or just have something shipped to you, like a SIM card. You get access to kitchen so you can save what you got by actually being able to eat decent, home cooked meals, plus you always got a table and a chair. You don't need any workarounds for showers, etc. There's typically a storage lockers in dormitories, so you can lock your essentials up. In two years working for three different hostels I saw something being stolen twice, one time the thief being caught within 15 mins. Other time someone jacked a pair of useless headphones, which I guess was plain bad luck. Don't look seedy. Have a good relationships with other staff and whoever runs the place.

Being full on homeless in UK is fucking retarded and lame. Constant rain and moisture, everything is mostly industrialized, country side is all farms and they've got even less tolerance for bums than cities, and almost all homeless are schizophrenics or junkies.

If you need some income you can just pick up a dishwasher job for a few weeks and then drop it. They pay weekly, so as soon as the cash goes into your account just don't show up.

>>2528809
Okay from someone in a totally different nation with an entirely different non suppourt structure I'll try some ideas out for you.

1 You need to make a list. This is a list of freinds. Couch surf with them. This will give you time and you can ask them about getting employment. If you have no freinds you will need to start a Couchsurfing.com account.
You will need to take that 1k gpb and NOT spend a fucking thing. It's emergency money. Keep it that way.

2 Having signed up for couchsurfing you are going to plane a way via stays into places that have better employment options. If you say you've applied 100 times I'm going to assume that's Online. Fuck online. I know they all tell you to apply online. Don't do that. That's the front of house telling you to do that so you can't speak to someone who might need to replace the person who told you that. print up a simple, 2 page resume. Explain you are in need of Long and short term work to sponsor an on foot expedition. Make it novel. You're not a bum- you are initnerant. Adventuring. It works. Makes you look deliberate not desperate. Remember that.

Next make sure you have shoes that look normal in normal ish clothing. Simple black or brown hikers that could pass for employment shoes. Not some super fancy goretex shit. Just something that is comfy and will last and be big enugh to help keep your feets good in the winter. Socks, shirt and under wear are more important than full sets of clothes.

You now have a way to stay somewhere. This is time. Time must be spend looking for a job. Ask everyone you stay with, if they have any ideas about jobs you can do to sponsor your "Trip" (this is what you call it, you aren't homeless you are travelling, always, understand?)

The next thing is while you are searching for these options, exhaust all welfare options, churches, donations for food. Get comfortable with a set of dumpster diving clothes and get comfortable with that often. Dumpster diving is a master art.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528809
The next thing is this couhc surfing has alternatives. WWOFers, BeWelcome;. TrustRoots. MovingWorlds. All are options if you can't do couchsurfings paywall.
The point is all you need is a place to sleep. Something to eat and a way to stay clean. These are not hard to do. If you don't have a drugs drinking or retard spending habit- you can do this very easily in the urban zone.

The gym membership thing is useful, but you want one that is common and near universal. Think cookie cutter type places like Planet Fitness if you are in the UK for example. The more the easier. This matters because hygrine matters.

The next thing you are going to do is map out libraries and get cards at all of them or one universal one if you guys do that. Libraries in the day are a great place to sleep for a while safely and having many gives you a free sleeping option everywhere. Be respectful and fold a book over yourself and they will often leave you alone. That's a free thing you cando but you will have the ngiht to consider. If you can get work at night and sleep in the day at libraries you'll be able to stack some cash up quick. Consider this option a baseline last resort. But you don't have many options at this stage

You wont die. You'll wander around bewildered that finally happened to you and that you didn't think about ways to mitigate homelessness in the first place. If your parants kick you out I have to ask if you've fucked around on them or not. Broken things, argued over shit, say home all day, been lazy etc. If you're one of those types then hobo mode will chew you up. mental health will go down hard. Sorry to say. But competant people don't stay homeless and turn all fucked up looking, They get employed asap because they have the drive of the risk of having to use more of the day just to do less.

I've been there in many ways, you need to exploit the freebies, stay clean and locate warm places to sleep that will accept you. Be a traveller insted.

it's about building codes/minimum standards for dwellings more than anything.

i'm guessing mostly it's the fact that jurisdictions haven't really caught up to living offgrid. there really should be a variance for these types of dwellings. if someone wants to buy some land and build their house, install septic, etc etc on their timeline, that should be their right. no one is going to buy a fucking house on a plot of land and then realize "oh shit, it's not on the grid, fuck me, i didn't bother to see if there was electricity!"

like my county (lane, OR) has minimum dwelling sizes, septic/mains/well requirements, etc etc; which make it either outright impossible to buy land, and build a homestead from scratch, or make the permitting/siting process take so long that construction loans aren't feasible. For example: getting a conditional use permit for a dwelling on F2 land requires at least 18 months of paperwork and waiting around while some 25 y/o nitwit planner looks for reasons to deny your build, meanwhile construction loans typically have a 1 year conversion timeline. wife and i lucked out and found a property that already had the CUP on it, otherwise there was no way we could have swung the land purchase and rolled it into our construction loan.

it's such a fucky situation, one that a lot of the naive 20 somethings here completely fail to understand. then again if it were as simple as rolling an RV onto a plot of land and going for it, there wouldn't be any countryside left. Some states are probably more amenable to this kind of thing, but the overall trend seems to be to make moving out into rural areas more and more difficult -- environmentalism gone wild coupled with a subtle/backhanded mommy government hatred of proles and independence.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2505999
Sure.

We do seasonal pigs here. That is, we purchase feeder piglets from a local farm in the spring, and then they go to the butcher in the fall. We do this specifically to avoid overwintering pigs and dealing with full grown breeders. It's a lot less work on our part and we don't carry the burden of the breeding stock.

Because of this we have a 1.5 acre forest pasture rich in acorns for the pigs to live on. They shop up when they're young and easily handled. Already cut and weaned. We purchase pig feed from a local feed mill that has very reasonable prices and sources somewhat locally. Pigs handle the feed well and grow quickly. We only usually need to deworm them once during this process. As the weather is mild they generally don't need much housing. They destroy anything you give them anyways, so their run in always looks like shit.

We keep 2 for our family and sell the other 3+ which pays for all 5+ pigs every year. Essentially we 'eat for free'. We sell half shares of pork to friends and locals who buy into all the buzzwordy meat stuff. This is why they go to a butcher, because there's some regulations there on how meat sales and preparation are handled. I send my two along as well because our butcher does a much much better job than I do and the pork sales cover it 100%, so why not.

People want to eat meme breeds so Berkshires are very popular, but hybrids are generally more vigorous and less likely to fail to thrive. Berkshire crosses is what we generally handle here.

In a small operation, this is the most cost effective and easiest method by far. Every year we look into buying a male and two females to start our own breeding program. Planning on keeping 5+ piglets and selling the rest, but the cost of everything skyrockets and piglet sales alone won't cover all the costs, so the operation starts operating at a loss and my goal is always to break even on food.

What does intellectual pursuit mean?

I have plenty of time to do whatever I want. Sometimes when I'm out doing chores I'll listen to audiobooks, especially if it's just splitting firewood or digging post holes or something else I can sort of tune out and enjoy the semi-meditative nature of the work. I read books before bed.

We can our own hides for buckskin and furs. My wife sews things for me and the kids like moccasins and wool clothing. We spend the winter months doing quiet things around the wood stove indoors. This time of year the days are so short and the outdoor work is really at it's lowest point we have plenty of idle time.

Summer is just busy as it can be. I routinely work sunup to sundown without much of a break. Unless you count the 9 to 5 as a break. There's gardening, animals to care for, chickens to hatch, firewood to log out and stack, always something needs fixing, or some animal in distress or whatever. Usually summer is the worst time to build things and run fence. That's best left for spring/fall.

There's plenty of time to do all manner of things. You just have to do them differently than you might expect. I don't have time to play video games much anymore, but I don't particularly miss them either.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2510648

Yes. There's plenty of time to do all of these things. You can attend university online, if that's what you want to do with your life. The pandemic put higher education on the internet for two years, and it's still running that way if you want to go the more traditional route.

I can find anything I need on the internet. I have the opportunity to get a Masters for free, and I can do it all via remote learning. Though, in my case, most of the classes are 'read two books, write a paper, read two more books, write another paper' style courses. I just have to do the paperwork to get started, but an advanced degree really won't affect my lifestyle or career at all, so I'm not in a rush.

I don't particularly see the point of any city. They're massive ultra consumerist shit holes. They produce absolutely nothing of value. They survive off of an infinite number of trucks constantly pouring in filled with goods produced elsewhere. I haven't voluntarily set foot in a major city in nearly eight years and my life is better for it.

If you live this lifestyle, it depends on how you live it. It's different for everyone. That will determine how much 'leisure' time you have. If you're really shitty and lazy you'll be too busy fixing your own fuckups to have much time to do anything else. But, if you're earnest and honest in your work and do it right the first time and never procrastinate or half-ass anything, you can have a lot of good down time to enjoy the fruits of your labor.

The lifestyle is also very seasonal. You'll be very busy in Summer, but very very not in Winter, assuming you did everything right. Now is about when I enjoy a full freezer and pantry and catch up on movies I missed during the year.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2510832
My grandparents had a farm and were farmers. They were retired when I was a kid, so I spent half the year out in the country in the middle of a farm community basically left to my own devices. I then read Hatchet and My Side of the Mountain and the other mandatory out books and it made me obsessed with camping and backpacking. I spent as much time outside as possible and had an aptitude for the farm chores and outdoor lifestyle.

I grew up, went to college, got a good job in the city and resigned myself to living the good urbanite lifestyle until I met my now wife. We both started hanging out and slowly realized with BOTH hated living in the city and wanted to live out in the woods and raise sheep and things of that nature. So we just left. Now we have several children and are making the homesteading thing work.

Resources for homesteading is a tough one. Nothing will ever be a stand-in for hands on experience. Most youtube videos are charlatans if not outright liars and I've actually somehow ended up helping out a few IG homesteaders with things like all their chickens dying from easily treatable illnesses that opened my eyes to how much the influencer crowd is just ignorant if not outright malicious.

I'll go through my homesteading bookshelf later, after I put the boys down for bed, and see if anything jumps out at me. Five acres and independence is a good book. The figures are out of date, but the concepts and ideas are timeless.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2507191
Yea keeping pigs ain’t always easy, financially speaking. I worked on a pig farm for a year during the onset of covid (in which it was eventually shut down due to pig prices plummeting), so I can speak on a few things.

Sometimes you’ll get a sow who after a 114-day gestation period births 16 piglets. Sounds great. But you have to consider some of the piglets die right away since they are worse than runts and can’t survive a day. So you’re down to 13. Then after detailing (literally cutting the tails off, otherwise piglets at 2 months will begin to bite the others, once there is blood, watch out!) you’ll have to give them proper shots to ensure their survival till market weight. During all this, you better make sure you have farrowing cages, otherwise the sow might accidentally roll over a naive piglet or two while she positions sideways for milking, or even worse yet, she may indulge in infanticide which is common with pigs. It happens even with farrowing cages, but much less so than without them. There will also be piglets that randomly die of unknown causes, so that further complicates things if your looking to profit.

When it comes to breeding, unless you are running a decent operation, keeping a boar around will prove costly for the fees needed, but also the upkeep like shovelling his shit every day or two. Also a boar will lose potency if not bred constantly. One sow every 200 days or so ain’t enough. I would probably just go for AI (artificial insemination) at that point. No boars, no rearing them. Just need fridge space.

Overall I think what you described (raising 5, selling 3 to “eat free”) is probably the best bang for your buck. I’m currently clearing a bunch of land for a terrace to grow some vegetables and friut trees. I might just buy 5 small pigs and let them run around in there and fatten them up. Sounds much better (natural) than actual pig farming lol

>>2515083
I’m still very early in the process anon, but I’m basically trying to revive my grandfathers lands, where my family has been for over 100 years. So there’s very much a feeling of being engrained with the land, and wanting to make the best of what I have in order to benefit me, my animals and my family.

We have about 5 acres right beside the house. 2 acres are right up beside the house, we usually just let our horse chill there, but we have partitioned it before to plant sweet potatoes, beans etc with great success due to the sunlight. The rest of the acreage lies below, most of it again is just mostly flat (with some slopes) pasture for the horse/cows, with a random lemon tree in the middle lol.

There is a part (picrel) that lies in a “grota” we call it in Portugal, that is home to about 4 orange trees, a bunch of other fruit trees of the Goyave family, and some wild yams. I’m personally trying to improve things first by cleaning up the entire area. There’s a bunch of weeds, invasive trees, and just general overgrowth that has appeared as the product of neglect. Once that is rectified, I will try to terrace and till some of the parts of the sloped portion. The flat part below will once again see banana trees, as had once been the case. We had to remove them since they are very laborious and need someone there year round to tend to it.

Great thing about where I am is that it’s December 27 and it’s 17 and sunny out, so a perfect time to do all this stuff before planting season, which for my area is February. I have a bunch of other ideas for chickens, pigs and other animals that I may elaborate on later!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Good thread bros but I feel like some of you guys are making a simple mistake. Being self sufficient doesn't mean having ALL your food and resources come from your property. That's impossible and it never worked like that in any point of human history.
The way they did it and we should do is have a main source of income (e.g. farming crops) and small side farming for your own use (chickens, a couple of cows, pigs, etc). You use your main income to sell and trade locally with your neighbors for whatever you need and the side stuff guarantees a good share of your nutrition.
If you're smart about it you don't even have to have huge land and wait years for your crops to be ready for harvest. For example a small 150 square meter barn can house 1000 laying chickens. They're laying eggs every day and you can butcher the old ones.
Another example is honey bees. It practically doesn't matter the size of your land since bees don't give a fuck about fences and will use all the land they have to feed. I mean of course you'll still make a sizeable initial investment but it may start praying for itself almost instantly.
Yeah it's not epic innawoods off the grid hermit but you get to that point after at least a decade of preppring anyway, so no sense in trying to go directly to that.
Now post homestead channels and waifus.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523907
Give yoursef 2 acres of woods for firewood, replant every tree you chip down. Get 2-3 cows, cycle them with either a bull or artificial insemination at different times of year so you get milk year round. You’re gonna want 3 acres of pasture for this. Keep it grass. On your last 2 acres, build your structures and use it for plants that you yourself will consume. Parta that you dont eat can be used to feed poultry or pigs. If I were you, I would buy a piglet every year and raise it for slaughter. You can let it supplement off pine cones or acorns and such in your woods. Take a quarter acre and grow corn to feed the pig. Take another quarter acre and put a pond on it, this is really important because you can periodically excavate the bottom layer of the muck and combine it with compost juice. The water in your pond can also temporarily fertilize your garden or your cow’s pasture. Try and srock your pond with fish that are able to attract and kill and eat insects. Attracting Insects for food should be your pond’s top priority, since insects cone from outside your property, and are thus an infinite source of food. Archerfish are my favorite but I dont think they necessarily breed. You want a fish that breeds more of itself. The fish themselves can be good winter sources of protein and bone nutrients for poultry.

My wife drives to the beach every sunday night and picks up a truckload of seaweed. We use it for poultry feed and compost. If you take an acre or so every couple years and leave it almost fallow, but with a twist: Plant a deep root plant like dandelion and let the roots go deep into the earth. Eventually you’ll want to root up all that dandelion so you can plant grass or some other plant. Well, here’s what happens: the dandelion will grab nutrients that have sunken far into the warth, below where your plants can get at them, and now you will be able to turn those dandelions into fertilizing compost to place back on the topsoil once again.

Anyone have experience with growing Apples in zone 2 or places with cold winters in general? I'm about to pull the trigger on 2 acres in Northern Saskatchewan and plan to use at least part of that on some apple trees. I'll be right on the border of 2b/3a, so my options for varieties are quite limited. I've heard that far north a lot of the time even hardy trees can lose all their grafted branches over time and end up producing crabapples. Has anyone experienced anything like that? Some people that I know in Southern BC manage to grow Mandarin Oranges by using plastic covers and christmas lights during the few truly cold days; would something similar be helpful in a real winter environment to deal with those days it spikes to -40?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534722
>people that I know in Southern BC manage to grow Mandarin Oranges by using plastic covers and christmas lights during the few truly cold days
Those are for the (very scares and few) days there where it dips in the 20s. Those parts of BC are a europe type maritime, very mild climate.

In northern Canada OTOH, deep in the center of the continent, you’re running a whole different ballgame. -40 degrees is just a whole different beast. My opinion is that you will have to grow your fruit trees inside of a thickly built greenhouse, with lots of thick brick or stone walls and thick glass, perhaps with some kind of built in heat blanket to come over the top during those polar vortexes which you’re gonna get and which will kill your plants. If I were you, I would invest in gas heating technology alongside a wood burner to heat the thing.

I’m not trying to demoralize you, just laying out the facts of what you should expect. Are you planning on keeping any cattle? Did you know that new technology permits us to harvest the gasses released by cows, and turn them into fuel? This is also possible with compost- capturing the gasses released during decomposition and storing them. I have seen hippy communities in Costa Rica successfully implement this technology. I think the cows might need a surgical operation for this machine to work though, IIRC. Not sure. That might set yousome kinda logistical limit since you’ll be so far out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534944
Zone 2 sounds damn hard. No personal experience, but a few things you can do come to mind.
Earthworks, walls and hardy shrubs and trees that shelter from prevailing winter winds are crucial. Kinda like a horseshoe shape, open to the south, closed to east west and north. Will also catch the sun in spring and warm up faster than flat land would. Extra points for big rock piles that act as thermal batteries.
For a nursery, you can dig trenches that you can cover up in winter. Below soil level will stay slightly warmer and may safe your young trees.
If you dig a bigger whole and put a glass roof on, you got a walipini. If it's big enough, you can put a couple trees in there too.
If you can get an excavator in for a day or two, that should be enough to prepare all these earthworks pretty fast and for not too much money.
Also look into passive solar greenhouses. Particularly from the rocky mountain permaculture institute. That's a little more involved and expensive, but would probably allow you zone 7 plantings inside. They grow bananas and figs up on a mountain in those things.
An attached greenhouse at the south of your house is also a very good idea. Gives you an extra layer of insulation for your home and the greenhouse profits from your heating. With some lights, you can probably grow winter greens continuously and extend you season enough to grow a couple proper tomatoes.
With all your greenhouse options, you can add a woodstove imbedded in a big thermal mass (brick or cob), that you can fire up in the worst parts of winter.
With all plants that overwinter outside, mulch them heavily for frost protection. Like 30cm+ straw, leaf or sawdust. You can also wrap stems and branches of your trees in straw and cloth.

>>2532017
I've spent about 4 months on and off over the past 3 years living in a minivan about the same size as the van in OP's pic. I've mainly stayed in cities, but I've spent some time out in the country in AZ/NM/CO.

>how feasible is this idea full time?
Not paying rent is pretty great. I feel like that's pretty much the only benefit. The worst part about van life is finding things to do when you're in an urban area if you're only working part-time. You'll have to find a way to shower, do laundry, and stay clean. If you don't have refrigeration or a stove, eating shelf-stable camp food gets boring after a few days while eating out everyday is expensive and unhealthy. If your van isn't insulated, the afternoons are hot and the early mornings are very cold.

>Would I get sick of it after a year?
Yes, especially if you don't have basic utilities. I have a pretty high tolerance to camping grit, and the longest I've lasted in a van was 66 consecutive days last spring (a combination of camping in AZ, NM, and then working in urban TX). In my opinion, it's a lot more sustainable to treat van life as an extended camping trip rather than full-time living. You'll look forward to van trips if you still live under a roof 10 months out of the year instead of feeling semi-homeless all of the time (pic related).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532017
The most I've done is a temporary hatchback conversion for a week at a time, so I'm not sure about vanlife.
Best advice is:
>have a shower system with hot water (propane)
Trying to do camp showers is suck and washing with cold water is very suck but exhilarating in its way.
>have a way to do good airflow wehn its raining
I've seen people cut in proper vents with shielding, which is best. It will require a decent battery pack, jackery gets mentions. Otherwise you're going to get the thing drenched in your own sweat and breath humidity or cook in warm months.
>small fridge
Again you also need a battery for it, but as other anon said eating camp food endlessly sucks.
>tables
Simple thing, but lacking work space sucks. Can use folding tables or have pull out ones, just have plenty of workspace, especially for cooking.

You want a vehicle that's 4wd with decent clearance. Also all the repair kit, including recovery (and watch safety vids please).
"Overlanding" is a good search term if you plan to do anything more rustic than parking lots and established campgrounds, but any vehicle popular in that community is going to have a +50% price tag on the used market.
Getting stuck if you go offroad is common, be prepared, calling tow trucks to come 25mi into the back country is both a full day wait and balls expensive, so know how to safely use recovery equipment and try to be smarter than the muddy ditch..

>>2533003
You don’t necessarily have to leave empty spaces but your options are limited. It’s something I deal with every year. You can either A:
>start your seeds in containers then transplant them after your spring/summer plants are done
Or B:
>only allow your current plants a certain amount of time in the garden
For example my fall plants (planted in September) only have 5 months to produce what they will and then I will pull them up soon to start preparing the space for my spring garden, but I also do some combination of the above where I only pull some plants when their time is up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533057
Experience mostly. Come up with a plan of what you intend on growing, how long it takes to germinate an estimate of when it will be to harvest. And strategize your planning around that. While you can't plant summer plants in spring, you can absolutely plant spring plants throughout the entire growing season ( I plant lettuce, arugula, carrots, kale, etc) all season long. With proper care, variety selection optimized for summer you can have lettuce and whatever the entire season. In order to do this you have to practice succession planting (planting a crop succesively every week or two to have continual harvest) You also need space to do this and an ability to crop rotate (when this plants coming out I have a new plant taking it's place.) Most summer crops happen to be fruiting plants (tomato, zucchini, etc) that are plant and done till they die from disease or the cold. So what I do is dedicate entire beds to my summer plants and work my spring/fall specific plants around that. I have two rows dedicated to trellising plants (tomatoes, cucumbers, pole beans) i intercrop determinate tomatoes with my climbing beans and bush beans with my climbing tomatoes and cucumbers. I have a row for peppers which I can intercop things like lettuce or radishes, whatever you want that doesn't take up to many nutrients. My garden is 8 30inch rows 45 feet long atm and when you map out an entire planting strategy my summer beds automatically rotate themselves to spring planting beds by next grow season. Draw diagrams of your garden space, figure out what you're planting and the harvest time and ask yourself if I want a continual harvest of something like carrots or lettuce what do I need to do to achieve that, where can I plant them, where can I plant my next row of them, etc. It requires very thoughtful planting but it's not hard to figure out the optimal strategy for your alotment

>>2534634
A single stake isn't a great idea, raspberries spread underground and send up canes all over the place. Raspberries can be a pain to grow in that regard. Usually I see people grow them up against trellising or use a Florida weave sort of set up to hold the canes up.

At my place we have a dwarf variety of raspberries instead though. The canes grow to ~50cm in height so they just end up looking like normal bushes when developed. Don't require much support, and if any is needed can just do stuff like put in a few stakes and tie thread around to make a basic cage to hold it up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534652
I've never specifically done barley, but I did do oats in a raised bed once. Definitely possible and not to difficult to grow, harvesting by hand sucks the biggus dickus though.

Canada says average yield for Barley is 65 bushels/acre, so assuming you can manage a similar amount of attention that a farmer does to a much smaller plot, you'll need 670sqft/bushel, or 17sqft/lb. So a 5'x3' bed will give you less than a pound of the stuff.

A quick google search suggests that you 2-3lb of barley for 5 gallons of beer. So if you wanted 5 gallons, you'd need to plant at least 34sqft of barley.

Seems pretty reasonable if you have some space, honestly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Those are lichen. You can see the lecanorine apothecia (the discs) in both photos. Afaik the spores aren't harmful and won't grow in you or anything: being obligate symbiosis, once they reproduce sexually via ascospores, they need to come in contact with the algal partner before they actually do much growing, which means at a minimum they'll need light. People burn wood with (apotheciate) lichen probably way more than they think, they are ubiquitous on many types of hardwood in particular. Source: trust me bro as look into investing in a used Brodo's Lichens of North America if that's where you live, it's expensive but worth it.

posts.com:
>>2530325
Baofengs get the job done for a great price but they felt like an expendable item when I held one. Biggest complaints from hamboomers is that they spray a lot of noise on transmit thus they can bleed over into other freqs, and that the receive is too sensitive so can perform poorly when other, undesired strong signals are nearby. This is an issue in all radios but supposedly worse on Baofengs. As a bonus, I believe they can be programmed to function on FRS/GMRS frequencies, which means you can talk to the regular walmart walkie talkies too.

Next level for ya'll innawoods might be setting up something like simplex(directly person to person, no repeater) DMR so you have a little more range and obfuscation(other DMR capable radios can understand you, but no one else can). More expensive radios, and it's a little complex to set up. But you learn a bit more and I think it's a good first step on the road to encrypted radio.

Best tip for VHF/UHF is that line of sight is king, and something like a N9TAX Slim Jim/Jpole can be put high up in a tree to get a lot more range, should you require it.

posts.com: You can't use them as a walkie talkie because of missing certified parts which are required. However you won't ever get caught unless you are an absolute menace on the air. Baofengs themselves won't break the rules that people care about if you stay on the FRS (family radio service) channels and switch to low txpwr max output wattage on FRS is 2w and low power is 1w. However I highly recommend just getting a gmrs license ($35 I think they just lowered the price, no test) because you can use those FRS channels up to 5 watts which is normal power and then the gmrs specific channels up to 50w+ repeater usage and you get a callsign.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532719
the problem with urban environments and radio is that in order to be able to punch through concrete, metal, wood, glass, etc you drastically reduce your overall range

Imagine radio signals to be like a 12" long piece of string. Higher frequencies (more squiggles) are better for punching through materials, but use up all of your 12" string so the overall length (range) is shorter

Lower frequency/HF stretches out the string- it can reach a farther distance but is less capable of punching through things blocking your line of sight.

polar bears even more so.
