posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533499
38 months. Australia. Many iterations. Walked a lot of states. Slept a lot of beaches, bummed a lot of rides. Made more money have having no rent while stopping for a couple of weeks doing picker trails.
Had sleeping bag, pad, hygrine gear, a good knife and passable working clothes that doubled as interview. Sandles for average wear, some non descrept shoes for work and stable standing. Most of the time I'd wind up bored and drifting to the nearest town then to the library. Food was so cheap in general from not eating out at all that foraging was all suppliment. Seasonal and mostly required local knowladge so stayed away from a lot of it. Too much of the difficulty now is in the gaps between areas that people live. The thing is it's easy to settle down, use employment to get basic materials and make a small hide. It's as simple as an A frame and a good water container for long term. But frankly people are so generous on the road that I never had much actual adversity that I didn't go out of my way to find. Especially when it came to bad weather, mostly heat related, I'd go read a lot. Eat some cheap end of day meals. Go to work the next day, showering at places that let me, rest stops in two cases and beachside in most of the urban zones. In the end keeping clothes clean wasn't even that hard as eventaully you hit civ and can launder. Working while wandering is key. Expenses eliminated you are reduced to
1 Make self clean and presentable
2 Sleep and wake up safely
3 Get money
4 Use spare time
5 Resist temptations to spend on stupid shit because no bills no thrills.
It's a great way to skill up if you have a nearby hobby. The money I saved from those 38 months became seed money fo later land ownership. As for wilderness, you need starup capital and specific gear in a place that no one checks much. Loads of that here and in the USA but euros are fucked.
Check Forest Anon for a more static equivilent of what I did. All you need is sleep and eat safely.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533499
After I failed all my college classes before I officially dropped out I went and climbed up the mountain near my college town and lived in a teepee for about a month. I didn't forage for my subsistence though. My calories came from rice and flour and canned raviolis and shit that I packed forest anon style. I only really foraged greens for my nutrients and electrolytes. And I was still a noob at that so really I just ate a bunch of wild onions and doughlas fir needles because I didn't actually know foraging yet.
It was pretty uneventful. Back in those days I was still idolizimg Chris McCandless and wanted to do the same thing. Just kinda sat around, chilled out, meditated, went into town once or twice to bag cigarettes and books. Didn't really do anything but relax without the distractions of responsibility or the internet.
Still the happiest I've ever been in my life. I want to do it again but now I'm kind of living paycheck to paycheck in an apartment taking care of my lazy ass wife and my kid who are dependent on me. And I dont Exactly want to destroy my entire life and become Perma-homeless.

i fell asleep sitting up and it hit me that a lot of sleeping gear is related to laying down.
i present a new concept: sit camping.
we've all fallen asleep while hunting, right?
so why fon't we just do that on purpose?

get yourself a wearable sitting pad, an army surplus marshmallow suit,
a poncho, and just lean against a tree next time you go to sleep.
this is the perfect ultralight camping setup. wanna leave? just stand up and start walking.
this is also good for innawoods shit because you can immediately react to a threat.

The purpose of this general is to encourage people to go /out/ and find cool fossils and artifacts. This thread is also a place to share our own collections and things we find when we are /out/ hunting.

>When you post about a fossil in your collection, please label it with what formation it is from, what it is, and where in the world it is from.

Plumbing will cost you a ton. If there is no public service, you'll need a septic system and youd have to get lucky that your area allows them AND that your land even passes the requirements needed. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2510676
it's getting harder, but still doable
we lucked out a bit and found a 3.5 acre plot about 35 miles from town (western oregon), that already had planning permission on it. it's forest land, so the state/county was super picky about allowing SFD's out here.

the way we did it was to go through a building company (adair homes) and get a construction loan.
>land: 60k
>construction cost on the house: 130k
>site dev: 50k (grading/ excavation/clearing the firebreak)
>septic/well/etc permit costs: 15k
>down payment: ~25k

the construction loan covered all the costs, and upon building completion converted to a conventional mortgage. it sounds expensive, but after the build was completed the property was valued at around 500k, vs the 260ish we financed. You definitely come out ahead when building vs buying (and no PMI). Our mortgage now is only $1300ish out the door.

Construction loans usually have a 12 month term, at which point you need to have the entire project completed. getting through the county took 4 months, and that was with the permit already in place -- otherwise it would have been a year for that approval alone. TL;DR plan on buying your land in cash, then hold off on taking out a construction loan until you know you'll be able to build (there's some obvious risk here, buy the land and the county could just say "no, you can't build here, for reasons".)

All this was done on 2 middle class salaries (135k household income), but that's kind of the minimum in 2022 to even buy a house, period. (which is a terrible omen of things to come in the US)

OP really isn't being unrealistic, it's absolutely possible to do this.

Usually people buy an RV or a caravan on a cost basis then build a storage shed, because you can't really avoid a storage shed. And this avoids installing septic.

i don't think you understand the hell that is involved in trying to split tracts of land up; that farmer would lose money on such a deal, a single acre is so small and worth so little, the fees would outstrip the sale price of a single acre plot. then there's all sorts of access easements, right of way concerns, zoning etc; it's a fucking headache. weyerhaeuser does this kind of thing after logging; but it's typically a larger tract (think like 100+ acres) but they parcel it off into 5 to 20 acre plots, then sell those. 1 acre is not worth anyone's time. This is all assuming it's actually rural.. closer to town the price of land increases enough to make it profitable to parcel out tiny mcmansion yards.

But all that is assuming the county would even allow it, oregon for example would almost certainly cock block that (planning goals here are basically designed to preserve farm and forest land.) Trying to develop formerly productive farm land into a SFD is going to take literally years, LUBA (thanks landwatch) proceedings take forever (assuming you win.)

If you had actually gone through the process of a build, or developing land at all you'd know it's not nearly as simple as you make it out to be.

This isnt really the full truth, they can only come after what they can really see. If you’re building a cabin in the woods, you dont have to worry unless you have psychotic neighbors. It’s very very hard to deternine what is what at ground level. Some basic concealment techniques will be all you need. They are not going to send helicopters to help conduct a search warrant of your property because there was too mich green in between the trees, or because a tree didnt look right. If they did this, they would be spending millions chasing ghosts. As it currently stands, there are huge plantations of illegal drug fields all over the country and the government is none the wiser. Hell, I know a guy who has had police show up to his unpermitted hut in the desert (for other reasons) and he has never been fined by code. Lol. Satellite imaging is used when someone complains, but really it in and of itself is more for finding more obvious structures. You’re never gonna get away with building an unpermitted mansion, at least not forever, unless you do it in a location where enforcement or rules are lax.

I know a guy in boomer retirement woodsy territory with lots of restirctions who built a detached office at the top of his hill, in plain view. No satellites, no cops, no drones, no helis. It’s been there for years now. I know a vuy in the open desert who has unpermitted solar pannels everywhere on his acreage, has had them for years, but no ZOG in sight.

Understand that there are a lot of strange people on the internet who try to dissuade you from doing things for some odd psychological reason. They will often cite laws, or even just make up laws. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532012
How much does a horse cost?
It's a complex question and will very much depend on what is the minimum you can live with and what you are willing to DIY. You say plug ins. Does that mean you want a grid attachment? In most places they'll only grid attach buildings that meet the code.
Before you get attached to the idea of grid, see if your needs can be met with a portable power station and a few solar panels. If you only use a low power laptop it's more than enough.
You say no insulation. But what about vapor barrier and sheathing for wind? How about windows? If you can 100% DIY and are comfortable living in a shed then the cost of an A-frame would be the cost of a chainsaw and a small amount of metal roofing from facebook marketplace or similar. You can get leftovers from other people's bigger projects for cheap.
If you want to learn conventional framing with 2x4s from the box store and put it on a concrete pier foundation like those used for sheds or outbuildings, and you wanted it finished with a typical shingle roof and vinyl siding, you're probably looking at north of 20k in materials cost.
Again though, it really really depends on what you are willing to learn, how much time you're willing to spend, and whether you are stubborn enough to do things 100% on your own.
If you want some inspiration watch a video on:
- cordwood construction. This is a method of building using cheap dry softwood logs as bricks in a DIY lime mortar. It's a niche technique here in the north. It's commonly used by single-family DIY teams that value a low-cost house over a low-labour house. It takes a lot of time to lay the wood bricks and for them to dry.
- shelter institute timber frame construction. This is a typical modern timber frame. They build with simple joinery but it would take a good amount of practice for a new framer to learn to maintain his chisels and cut the joints properly. The lowest labour finishing technique for these houses is to use SIPs.

get a house as passive as possible, very insulated, be as independent as possible ie don't buy shit you cannot fix or are reliable, have a big pantry and get long time shelve food in there, if you have a farm start looking into putting some fruit trees as they will take years until they are productive (better if are the kind that you can plant vegetables or grain bellow it), stcok seeds for your farm, prepare low tech irrigation systems for said farm, try to get solar or whatever but keep it as simple as possible, both to have less possible problems but also too look less prepared, a 7kw solar installation will catch attention which a 750w one would probably not.

never understood 'preppers' who let you know they are preppers.
seems like if someone knows you are a prepper, you've already fucked up.
example:
that dumb discovery channel show about preppers
>guy has a fucking underground vault installed in his suburban backyard.
>family runs drills practicing evacuating the house in god damn hazmat bunny suits
>neighbors seeing all of this happening
guess which house is going to be ransacked first? or suddenly the entire neighborhood is there to appropriate your bunker?

No amount of 'prepping' you can actually do will ever be enough, given enough time. All you can do really is increase the chances of survival by lengths of time and hope society unfucks itself or settles down before that time expires. Far enough north to avoid people, good luck when you run out of diesel fuel, bar oil, or any of the consumables needed for 'offgrid' living. Farther south, it'd be an unending swarm of locust-like refugees denuding the landscape and eating anything that moves. Comfy holler surrounded by like-minded family/friends/neighbors? You'd last the longest, but eventually machinery breaks and aforementioned consumables run out. Best case scenario is living in the 19th century until the hordes win out.
Hungry people don't stay still.

i know this is an unpopular opinion here; mainly because it goes against the weird LARP obsession that devolves into theorycraft about how rugged and self sufficient we all think we are. But the tendency is to focus on immediate needs without any thought at at all the longer term. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528822
>prioritize
1. Know your area. Understand what resources you will be working with.
2. Flint knapping. If you can't make hard, sharp edges you're toast. Absolutely essential.
3. Cord. Pretty simple skill to pick up and the precursor to many other utilities.
4. Fire kit. You can use the cord you make for a bow drill which will make your life much easier as you will be starting campfires often.
5. Snares, traps, nets. Squirrels and fish are much easier to come by and process than big game. You will have to hunt at times but trapping is more reliable and less burdensome.
6. Basket weaving. You'll want to keep the various goods you forage for in separate containers.
7. Improvising shelters. You could probably throw something together without giving it a great deal of thought but the more you know about bush architecture the comfier your camps will be.
8. Pine tar adhesive. Once you have this in your repertoire you will be able to seal your baskets and make them watertight, among many other useful applications.
9. Processing hides. You won't be able to do top-quality leatherwork but you should be able to do well enough to clothe yourself and perhaps make a nice tent if you feel like hauling one around.
10. Everything else. Bushcraft is an extensive subject and if you have time before the collapse anything more you can pick up will contribute to your advantage. Good luck, Anon.

posts.com:
>>2528822
Good contacts to trustworthy people from your community, country and around the world.
First aid knowledge.
Knowledge of your surroundings, how to reach important points (friends, towns) without maps.
Knowledge of wild plants to use or to avoid.
Vaccinations, all memes aside.
How to start and extinguish a fire.
Build up tolerance to cold and bug bites.
Basic strenght and stamina (climbing a tree or wall, long hikes)
A good amount of body fat.

All things you prep and put together are worth shit when you have to move an can't take them with you or loose them. Skills and your body stay.
Enough stuff to live comfortably for a few months and a good bug out bag is great and you should have that for comfy low level happenings or a personal collapse but if you really want to 'be prepared' you should expect life as a refugee with nothing.

PNW, so bigleaf maple mostly (Acer macrophylum). It is moderately shade intolerant. It can grow in the understory, but to achieve the branching structure we want open is better.

>>2533463
Ya anon I did a lot of solo backpacking and knew my outdoors shit when I lived in the gta. I moved up north and bought a kevlar 2 man from a cottage company, Its light enough i can solo it but if i have a friend its super easy to portage.
Its not too different from backpacking or camping its easier and more fun in ways. If your not experienced you can “car camp” from your canoe. Just load it up with all the shit from your car and find a nice spot on the lake for the night, you can envision what you would need and to leave behind if you were going to be travelling with the canoe and a pack.
For general tips:
-A cheaper one will be heavy but if you have a lot of people its not so bad
-kevlar canoes are more expensive but very light
-good paddles make a difference, the $40 canadian tire ones work but if you try $100 paddle you will immediately change your mind about that being a ridiculous price.
-good lightweight life jackets that actually function. I like to go as lightweight as possible for solo trips while still being comfy so i bought a self inflating lifejacket thats basically a small non-restrictive harness, it has a valve that when immersed in water inflates the vest like an airbag. It was expensive but its very small and light, super worth it on long portages. I also know for a fact it works and would save my life.
Do you have experience regular camping or backpacking?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533463
lots of portaging kind of "requires" a light canoe, and most of the big ones are very expensive. solo canoes are light though and you can avoid high prices that way. i don't know about in canada, but here in the US you can find older aluminum Grumman canoes all the time for like $400-700. most often it's the 15ft and 17ft models. they are not light, but a very good bang for your buck considering how durable and longlasting they are. a 15ft can be portaged if you pack lightly and are decently strong.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I want to watch birds when I go into the mountains, I think I would enjoy that very much.
Nudge me in the right direction for buying some nice binoculars. Would 10x42 be sufficient? Surely there's a sweet spot for magnification/lens and weight.
I'm thinking about spending 200-300 Euro dollars.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532510
The people that need Binoculars watch birds in their yard; drive to nesting spots in open fields/wetlands, or who go to shorelines to watch the seabirds. I've been an avid bird watcher for decades and never take binoculars into the woods with me...because they're pretty useless in the woods. Much of the time you'll only ever hear them but many birds are very curious and will come check you out...they're usually hard to spot because they're stealth as fuck and too fast for binoculars anyways. Ironically some of the best birding areas are near light density urban areas. Depending on where you live Migratory birds can be coaxed into your yard after a year or two of leaving out feed and you really don't have to go to them.
All that said just get a heavy as fuck pair of high power binoculars, some good regional bird books, and accept you're going to spend more time on the trail (in the woods) figuring out the bird songs than ever seeing anything.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532510
8x42 or 10x42 is the "standard" when it comes to somewhat compact binoculars that also perform good in low light. If you want truly compact binoculars, I would recommend Vortex Diamondback HD 8x32. They have a very wide field of view, and are much lighter/smaller than 42s. of course you trade off some low-light performance compared to 42s. It all depends on what you prioritize and how you carry them also. if you keep them around the neck, you notice every couple of ounces. I feel that the 8x32 diamondback hd hit the "overall" sweet spot for everything, but 10x42 are better for really getting in close on something that might be further away.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532816
because monoculars have fallen out of favor. they are inferior to binoculars in terms of comfort/eye strain, and rangefinders have added features but arent meant to be used for extended looking. do yourself a favor and buy some quality compact binoculars like the diamondback hd 8x32. they're pretty small and light. they will fit in a small belt pouch or waist pack.

>>2500079
>any of you /out/ists taken the offgrid cabin pill yet? howd it go?
I've been off grid for 5 years but get called a larper whenever I post so kind of gave up contributing. I bought a cheap single bedroom cottage in rural NE Victoria (australia) because it was close to a dairy farm I was managing that was already on septic and tank water. Everything works. I have a normal kitchen and office and can blare music and play video games like any other person. All my power tools are corded but the inverter has no trouble powering a pressure washer or angle grinder. A few solar panels and an inverter was all it took to take it completely off grid. Having the rain water tank at ground level is the biggest drain on my power though, every time I turn a tap there's a 50W jet pump that goes brrrr and draws the same power as a microwave running on high. Keep your rain water at roof-gutter level instead of ground level to allow gravity to keep the water pressure up so you can at least shit and shower if the power goes out. My house looks like any other 1960's Australian fibro cottage but I take a working holiday every couple of years to Taree as a cattle drover and stay in pic-related.

I want to talk about how hard it is to be green, but it really isn't. I just gifted most of my shit to grateful friends when I was 28ish and have room to move now

Thanks anon. Sounds sad, but I don't get many replies here and that made my day. I forgot to mention a few really important problems with the house earlier: the dismal internet situation in rural australia. Satellite is the only option and I pay $70 a month for the fastest and largest plan available (250gb in air quotes) which is only 60gb "on peak" and the other 150 when they feel like it at 1.5mbps max. Petrol and diesel are at least 70c a liter dearer than the nearest "town", and you can forget about buying fresh produce from the local "supermarket" when they feel like opening. Sorry for so many quotes. But real shit for anyone who's into it: Living in the middle of nowhere off the grid is rad, but be prepared to spend a whole day doing simple chores like grocery shopping or visiting a doctor/pharmacy etc. Expect to replace your tires more often and do way more car maintenance. And a big one is to expect your friends to completely forget about you when you're too far away to hang out with and you drop off social networking. It could be a good or a bad thing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2516929
>that should absolutely be their prerogative
Not really, no.

The main goal is to protect and increase property taxes. The preventing a shanty town is part of this. As a secondary goals, they want to make sure you are dealing with your waste water properly. Some areas also want to make sure you are only using your share rain and ground water. And don't forget your municipality is probably providing waste and fire services. There's also the fact you are going to be selling your property at some point - it's all very well building and living in your own death trap shack but once you sell it the next guy won't know how much of a death trap it is.

Zone also governs land use - some land is reserved for agriculture, some for living, some for industry. You wouldn't want your country idyll destroyed by a neighbour setting up a motorcross track or gravel pit.

But you must know that these zoning laws only apply in some areas, not everywhere. Get as far from a city or town as possible and you should be fine. Don't expect to get away with a shack if you are in a beautiful valley, next to a beautiful lake, within a walking distance of the store. Many areas have a loophole that you can get away with a lot less infrastructure if your house is on wheels.

And really importantly, if you want to be left alone in your shack don't be a moron and mail out bombs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Have you gone over all the different aspects of a functional cabin? Where are you going to poop? Where is your water coming from? How will you store food? Does it need heating/cooling?

For example... My land had nothing but trees on it. So I put a trailer on it (old one that was practically being given away) then I had a well dug for water supply. That was expensive but worth it. Then I had a septic tank and field put in for the trailer... Somewhat expensive and a hassle to get it perked, but nice to be able to use my toilets and not have to go on a short hike everytime I needed to poop. Then I had electric hooked up.... That cost money too because they had to install poles and run the lines to the trailer. Also, they may refuse to hook up electric if they think your cabin is not safe enough.

Not trying to discourage you... It would just suck to put thousands of dollars into this only to realize you forgot that you need a clean water source to live. I was without it for a while and relied on bottled water.... It's insane how much water we use and how quickly things get crappy when you are having to ration what water you do have.

>>2534046
can confirm, 3 acres is enough for a house and a yard -- and a garden/shop; but no where near enough for privacy/feeling like you're in the woods.
we bought 3.4 acres a few years back and like many naive people on this board, we thought:
>holy shit it's so much land, what will we do with it all.

But after clearing the firebreak, and the people to our north cleared their firebreak, there's not a ton of undisturbed forest left. i can hear their dogs,tools, conversations. they're on 5 acres, and their house is ~100' away from my window

luckily we were able to buy the property to our south (another 3.8 acres), and we're keeping it forested. Farther to the south and west is BLM wilderness, so there's that (east is another house, but much farther away, and they have 10 acres of their own). But if we were bordered by people on all sides it would feel very much like a suburb with egregiously large lawns.

you want as much land as you can get, the exception being where your jurisdiction allows you to site your dwelling. my county (lane, or) has this insane notion that houses need to be clustered together on roads/utility easements. so you might have 40 fucking acres, but you'd be forced to build RIGHT ON THE ROAD. in that instance, 5 acres with a secluded house would be preferably to 40 acres, but no privacy.

Good week for mushrooms ahead edition

>Community-based tools for IDing and Cataloguing
Mushroomobserver.org
The Bolete Filter: https://boletes.wpamushroomclub.org/
Inaturalist app (directly draws data from mushroomobserver but is itself a more generalized platform)
Google Scholar: Massive resource for papers and studies regarding current clinical and indigenous uses of medicinal fungi.

If you expect to get a remotely meaningful ID here, you need to be taking photos of the mushroom as you found it, on it's substrate, a clear shot of the top and side view of it, and a clear shot of the gills/pores/stipe/stem or otherwise the entire undercarriage of the mushroom. every detail of the encounter helps, where, when, what was the weather, etc.
If you want people who do this for a living to give their guess on ID's, take all of the above and make quality observations on Mushroomobserver.

This science needs as much redundant ID and loacation data as possible, any observation has value and is a meaningful contribution that takes a few more seconds than just taking a picture of the pretty thing you saw in the woods.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2506039
>How can I make mushrooms to proliferate in an area so the following year has a larger amount of them?

The fruiting body you see on the surface is just one small part of the fungi. Beneath the surface is a mycelium system that spawns the fruiting bodies in an area that consistently produces mushrooms. I assume the best way to proliferate a desired fruiting body is to first proliferate mycelium growth (maybe by spreading nutrient substrate around the area), or to spread spores over the desired area during ideal weather conditions and over an ideal substrate in ideal locations to promote growth (ie under a damp log or on moist sheltered leaf litter during a cool rainy season, dependent on species). Both methods are dependent on local weather and light conditions, because they are done outside of a controlled environment. Large colonies also take a long time to grow and cover a large area, there are many examples in both the eastern and western US of colonies that are hundreds to thousands of acres in size and they are estimated to have taken hundreds to thousands of years to attain that much area. Might be worth a try, I'm not an expert.

i've never done anything but innoculating directly into pre-sterilized injection port bag of either millet/milo or rye, shaking up the bag once there's colonization, and then repacking it into a block. and just open up the grow bag for o2 when it's colonized, they'll fill the entire empty space on top of the block with fruit.

that's the best way to do low-sporulating strains as far as i've ever heard, if you try that with golden teachers or otherwise high sporulating strains you're just going to have a thick layer of spores on top of the block which is begging for contamination before a 2nd flush happens

point being the first flush is literally 99.99% guaranteed unless you somehow injected contamination in with the spores, zero stress zero doubts, zero equipment, just substrate bag and spore syringe.

if you're so inclined you can throw the colonized grain in with your choice of tub substrate mix if you are specifically trying to get 2-3+ flushes, it's still the safest way to get colonized grain in the first place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2509836
>tub first timer grow, golden teachers
stop
buy sterilized rye grain or milo millet in injection port bags, innoculate modestly, don't shoot 10ccs into a 3lb bag, let it colonize, shake it up, let it fully colonize from there, and simply open up the top of the bag when it's ready to fruit. you don't need some magic combination of substrates to make this work, you put them alone in a bag of food, they find all the food they have access to, then you give them O2, keep them wet and warm and they fruit, it's that simple.

ESPECIALLY for high sporulating strains like golden teacher, you are basically going to get 1 flush, and then the entire top surface of your substrate is going to be painted black/purple with spores and is basically guaranteed contamination. save the fancy tub grows for some of the nicer, pickier, and lower sporulating strains.

protip you can turn 1 syringe of spores into pretty much unlimited colonizing fruit blocks if you either immediately move colonized grains into a bag/container of grains you made yourself (less than sterile but it won't matter, strain boiling water over it and you'll be fine, nothing to lose and it means you buy less spores from TOTALLYLEGALDRUGGROWING.COM)
or literally collect the spores in Agar and put em in your fridge to colonize. get a head start on your first attempt and you'll have unlimited attempts to get it right, or simply do the same thing again and get more shrooms.

seriously, don't overthink how fucking easy it is to grow some of the "beginner" strains, don't overthink sterilization and optimal anything, just do the first paragraph of this post and you "Will" have mushrooms, anything else turns that into a "Probably". but you should have unlimited "probably'"s with just the 1 syringe and a bag of rye or millet from the tractor supply store near you, i'd say good luck but it's too easy for luck

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2510742
Preserving spores is worse in every circumstance than preserving living liquid/agar culture

Starting with spores is a genetic gamble plus they take extra time to germinate. Your mushrooms will all grow at different rates too.

Whereas using living mycelium skips germination and is a clone of the specific mushroom you took it from and you have a better chance of your mushrooms growing at the same rate (leading to the coveted mushroom canopy).

>gather the mushrooms before the veil is fully separated to avoid spores falling because that's what signals to the mycelium to stop fruiting
This is true

So basically my process is:
>leave PC’d bags on shelf next to hood
>open master spawn bag
>grab bag from shelf, spray down with iso, noc up, seal, grab next bag while sealing, shake and place on shelf after sealed

I hunt mushrooms because it takes me to places other people don't go or skip over. There's four different prizes to win:
>1. Fresh, edible mushrooms that you can't get in any stores
>2. Deadly mushrooms that you can say you've seen and identify
>3. Unusual-looking mushrooms that are fun to look at
>4. Psychoactive mushrooms that you can grab off the ground for free

There are no mushrooms that are dangerous to touch or even taste as long as you don't swallow them. I started by just going out and finding mushrooms, then trying to identify them with an app or book while out there. I started reversing that, targeting a mushroom that grows in my area to go out and find. Once spring starts there are certain species I want to find and clone and grow them myself.

The number one rule is don't eat anything that you aren't 100% sure on

>>2522239
gold oyster are SEA native warm tropic natives as far as I know but if you're in CA or florida I can see it being normal,

wait for the actual msurhoom fruit and get spores directly from the best individual mushrooms you can find, I've successfully done this with oysters just smashing up the fruit body and mixing it with oak substrate, oysters will out-compete just about anything in the long run in a body of substrate. that is how you narrow down the phenotype into the biggest most agressive mushrooms.

you can harvest the myceleum and just put that straight into substrate but that's a huge gamble, you'll almost definitely grow something but it's a coin toss. if you see a perfect mushroom, you want spores from that actual mushroom, not necessarily from that mushroom's mycelium body.

>>2523197
So I use the producer prides whole oats and all I do is add 920g of oats per bag, then add 600g of water(this is the equivalent of 4 mycoquarts per bag). Then I flash prep a quart and a half of wbs(bring water to a boil, take off the heat, add the wbs to the water and cover with a lid for 15 minutes. And after that I just add half a quart of the flash prepped wbs to the top of the oat bags. PC for 3 ½ - 4 hours. And then done.

Some people say you have to do a hot shake in order to redistribute the moisture in the grains but I don't do that and haven't had any problems. A hot shake is when you take the bags out as soon as the PC is depressurized and shake it around in front of your hood, but I just leave it in the PC to cool over night before I fuck with them. Plus if I do the hot shake then I mix all the wbs around which makes the lc recover slower since its all spread out. When I noc the bags I pour lc on the wbs at the top of the bag and it recovers fast

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530319
And after that I just add a half PINT* of the flash prepped wbs to the top of the oat bags**

Obvious you can go over that and use a full pint/half quart if you want, it will just mean you have a bit more spawn in your bags, but this is for a cycle of 6 bags since all I got is my presto at the moment

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530319
Oh and I forgot to mention to strain the wbs after you let it sit in the pot of boiled water for 15 minutes, but you probably already knew that. Personally I strain it by dumping the pot in my kitchen sink with just the little drain strainer since its easier and less mess but you can use a strainer if you want I guess. I've seen people secure a window screen over a tote or a strainer inside a bucket, but to me that's just another thing to clean and another way for bird seed to get everywhere. And some ppl say you gotta wait ~30 mins for the water to strain. But since its only flash prepped and not fully hydrated you don't need to wait, just start loading it in the bag after like 3 minutes of letting the water drain. They'll finish hydrating fully during the PC cycle. I do it the same way for jars too and they always come out perfect, barely any bursted grains.

And 1 more note: I said the flash prep for this is 15 minutes in the boiled water but that's only because its a small amount of wbs. If you're doing flash prep for a bigger load like 10 quart jars or if you're doing 100% wbs bags then you want it to sit in the boiled water for like 25-30 mins instead

>>2531763
Not the poster, but the typical method is.

You would take a small piece of mushroom from the inside of a good looking specimen. This tissue culture will be placed onto an agar petri dish. From this sample mycelium will grow. After it's grown out a bit, you will take a small sample from the first agar plate and transfer it to a new one. Assuming the culture is clean and free from contaminants, wedges from this dish will be used to inoculate sterilized grain. This grain is allowed to colonize with the mushroom mycelium. Once colonized, the grains will be added to bags of hydrated sawdust and wheat bran. The mushrooms grow from these bags.

>>2531857
>why is agar used? does it have to be agar?
Agar is just a substance that can be easily steralised and has plenty of nuetrients for the mycelium to use to grow. There probably is agar alternatives, but agar is cheap and works well.

>Why is the mycelium from the second agar plate used? Is it to reduce the likelihood of contaminants (fungi/bacteria)
Yes, the first plate and syringes/swabs may contain mold spores and other contaminants from the air.

>Does this mean the whole process can be repeated by taking small pieces of mushroom from the new grown mushrooms & regrowing the mycelium in agar again
Yes, I'd reccomend looking into culture slants too for long term storage of mycelium.

>>2532612
I don't preseal to dry bag, I just accordion fold the dry bags in the PC to prevent water of the PC from leaking into the bags and/or water leaking out of the bags. I'm saying I seal them after I take them out the pc cycle because I was afraid of leaving the bags on my shelf unsealed before I have a bunch prepped for inoc day.

And if you're wondering how I'm able to stack 6 dry bags without submerging the bottom bags in the water; I just use 2 quarts of water for the presto instead of the standard 3 quarts, this in conjunction with putting a few quarters on the rocker prevents the PC from drying out. I always have plenty of water left, even after a 4 hr cycle

I've had my presto for 3 years now and still haven't replaced the gauge lol. I think the gauge worked properly for like 10 cycles before it started to giving a false reading. At the very beginning the rocker would shake when the dial hit 15 psi, as it should. And this was without adding the quarters to the rocker. Then it would shake at 16.5 psi, indicating that the gauge is off by 1.5 psi. Now I have the quarters taped to the rocker and run that bitch at 19-19.5psi, the rocker only shaking occasionally during the cycle. Basically I use the gauge as like a rough estimate of where I need to be, but depend on the state of the rocker to tell me what psi I'm at.

Only thing I've replaced on my presto is the sealing ring and the safety plug. Since I don't have my AA yet I kinda have to finesse this presto the best I can lol. Soon I will replace the gauge just because the rubber grommet is starting to disintegrate so I think its due time now. But it hasn't caused me problems so far.

Not sure how different my process of dry bagging is going to change when I get the AA, but I'm hoping I can make it work because man I fucking love dry bagging and I don't wanna turn back to prepping grain again lol

>>2533035
Vaseline actually degrades rubber, you're supposed to use a light coat of cooking oil for prestos as instructed in the manual. I don't even apply it to the gasket. I apply the oil on the metal rim of presto(I think this is also mentioned in the manual). Vaseline is only for AA's since its metal to metal.

After about a year when the gasket starts to shrink you can also just stretch it with your hands so that it fits snug again. Just be careful not to stretch it too hard or you'll cause a tear in the rubber like I did a few months ago

But yeah even though I've only had my presto for 3 years, I was able to get make the gasket last 2 years before I had to replace it. And I really only had to replace it because I went macho man mode the last time I stretched it out lol

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533044
>Vaseline actually degrades rubber
Yeah, that was probably honestly a big part of it. It rots the rubber. The idea behind is that by sterilizing it all the time though, you're not giving the bacteria much chance to set up camp, and it's more cost effective to run it until it breaks like this than it is to buy a proper lubricant, like silicone oil. But I didn't know cooking oil worked, the manual only said
>If necessary, to help make the cover easier to open and close, a very light coating of vegetable oil may be applied to the sealing ring and underside of the body lugs (Fig. B). The cover should open and close easily when following the instructions on page 5, step 7.
It didn't say it was helpful to extend the life of the gasket in general, but reading more on it I see it does apparently. Wish I had known that.

>And I really only had to replace it because I went macho man mode the last time I stretched it out lol
That's usually how I ruined mine too. Especially when they were hot. If I didn't stretch them enough, it'd leak steam when running, so I'd notice that then pop the lid and try stretching only to snap. I only went through 2-3 rings in like 5-7 years (I had three 23 qt prestos), but those 2-3 were in the same few months when I was really picking things up, and I didn't want to end up wasting say $200+ on perishable parts over a couple years when I could've just bought an AA and saved time and money. I miss having a stovetop PC though, probably gonna grab an AA 921 during canning season this year.

>>2533050
My bad I meant veg oil when I said cooking oil. You def don't wanna slap some lard on your presto lol.
>pop the lid and try stretching only to snap
I never stretched it while it was hot, I would clean the gasket after a cycle and then when I was ready to use it I would stretch it while it was room temp. It really doesn't even need to be completely snug. Like even if there's a 1-2mm gap the rubber will expand as it heats up. I never had my presto leak steam. I'd wager on the use of Vaseline as being responsible for messing up the gasket and causing the leaks

And btw thanks for the tip about the AA gauge and being careful with the threading. I'll def keep that in mind because I want it to last me forever lol. I try to take very good care of my equipment. Even before the first time I used my presto I read hella info and instructions about it and watched a ton of videos. Even on just basic canning because I wanted to see if maybe there were some vital info that I otherwise wouldn't learn from presto users that were solely using it for shrooms. For example I learned from a canning dude that its better to build up to temperature slowly that way you don't get swings in temp/pressure. Almost every single youtube grower I've seen never does this, they just leave their stoves element on high until it reaches 15psi before turning the heat down.

>>2533310
Just web-search "[STATE] Spore Syringes" and you'll probably find something. Mycelium quickly colonised all of the petri-dish. They'll last 2-3 months at best of you leave them in the fridge. A slant has much more volume for the myceilum to slowly into and will last 12-18 months. Ideally "refreshing" them every 12 is a good idea. You can also mess around with dry spore storage. Dry spore prints in theory can last many, many years. I haven't touched that though since rehydrating them can be unreliable.

>Is it an activity typically done outside?
Walking from the entrance to a building to your car is also an activity typically done outside, so I'm afraid it's not quite that simple. Other activities typically done outside:
>taking the dog for a walk
>landscaping, yard work
>music concerts
>sports events
>circuses, fairs, carnivals, etc.
>farmer's markets, street markets
>farming and agriculture
>roofing, painting, etc.
So as you can see, there mere fact of doing something without having a roof over your head doesn't qualify an activity as /out/. Personally I've long been on the fence about metal detecting, because it requires an electrical device and typically involves not going innawoods but in fact deliberately staying near populated areas where people are/were likely to have dropped, lost, or buried shit.

Most people on thru hikes don’t have time or the inclination to actually cook food at the end of a day of hiking. Food weight matters, as does fuel. There’s also the matter of time, though that’s minor. Shelf life and packability come into play as well.

Since you said it was a thru hike and specifically singled out freeze dried meals, I’m guessing you haven’t looked too much into what people are actually eating. They’re not eating ready made freeze dried stuff. Think of it this way: where do you generally resupply on a thru hike, and do those places sell free dried meals? Walmart is about the only exception, but generally you’ll be in a small town grocery store (or a gas station or Dollar General or something, depending on the trail and logistics).

Pic is true for thru hiking in the US. It’s mostly junk but that’s what people are bringing. The sodium content is fairly high, but you’re not eating this while sitting on the sofa. And f you’re on a popular trail every third or fourth day you’ll be in a town and can buy actual food.

I have the same issue. I'm based in Europe, but you should be able to get everything in a flyover land convenience store as well.

What you need is fibre. Oatmeal is pretty rich in fibre, lightweight, cheap and easy to prepare. I eat it once a day. Dried fruit like apples, figs or plums are also great. Don't get the half dried stuff because it tends to go bad. If you buy pasta, get whole wheat pasta (smaller size cooks faster, so less fuel). Granola bars work too but often they have too much sugar for me. And whenever you are in town, got some fresh vegetables, fruit, canned lentils, beans or chickpeas.

Minimize processed carbs like white bread, cookies, ramen, ect..

Happy shitting, anon.

>>2529916
No. In fact some grocery stores don’t even stock pepperoni in a refrigerated case, but just on a regular aisle. Same with various hard sausages and summer sausage. Of course they will eventually go bad after they’re opened, some faster than others, and all depending on ambient temperature.

Cheese is probably the worst. I bought extra sharp cheddar a few times on hikes where I had to resupply, and I could never finish the entire 8oz block before it started to look too funky (it gets soft, oily, and a little discolored). Maybe if I was going further in cooler weather it would have made sense, but it was always warm and only 4 or 5 days until resupplying.

I never had any issues with sausage or pepperoni, even on a 7 day stretch in Alabama. Pepperoni does get kind of brittle (compared to when it’s fresh), and it sweats a little, but I’ve never had it stink or get rancid or anything. Same with summer sausage, but I’m not a big fan. The artisanal sausages and salamis you can sometimes find in larger stores hold up well too, but they’re not widely available like the pleb tier stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When I did a large part of the pct I mailed myself packages to post offices/ski areas/etc. at my parents house I made individual flat rate usps boxes and loaded them with food but didn’t seal them so extra requests could be added (ie batteries, spare shoes, spare socks etc) only when I needed them. I had a schedule of when I needed the things put in the mail to get there in time (some places don’t hold mail indefinitely), which I called and modified based on my pace.
I bought most of my food from Costco because the bulk quantities make the membership worth it.
I ate about 8,000 calories per day and burned 10,000 (was losing 2 lbs/wk). I had a bear can I wanted my food to fit in so I needed to maximize my calories/volume AND my calories/weight. (As I recall my biggest leg between resupplies was around mt hood, 5 days, which didn’t totally fit in my bear can). I think about half my calories were candy- mostly nutty candy like snickers, peanut m&ms etc. I liked the candy-rich diet because instead of waiting 30 minutes to cook food and eat it you could literally eat the candy while walking, then sleep immediately at the end of the day. This extra 30 minutes per cooked meal is equivalent to about 1.5 miles, which can really add up over many weeks.
Candy is the ideal mix of fat, protein, and sugar, and it’s tasty enough I never got sick of it. I ate enough regular food (jerky, gorp, rice, beans, pasta, tuna, pb&j, etc) that I wasn’t worried about micronutrients so having a nice mix of macros in candy was fine. I also augmented when I came across stores/restaurants for fresh food like ice cream, fruit, cheese, beer, etc
I brought exactly zero freeze dried anything because it’s extremely expensive and bulky and low calorie. The highest possible calorie food is pure fat (I had olive oil that I sometimes added to everything to bring up the calories in some foods like Mac and cheese substantially).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533347
Also, the monotony of food *texture* is real. A game changer for me was making instant pudding- a package of instant pudding and a package of instant milk, in a ziploc bag with very cold purified stream water. Close the bag and massage it for a few minutes til it’s combined and hardens. Then cut a small corner off the side of the bag and squirt it directly into your mouth. It’s not ice cream, but the cold creamy consistency is so different from most other foods you have it will be an amazing dessert. And there’s no dishes, which is a nice plus.

>>2533605
Although some freeze dry is denser than others it’s all pretty bad- rough approximation is “does this float”. A bag full of freeze dried food would be a good life preserver, a bag of candy not so much. I fit most of 100,000 calories in my bear can for my Pct leg near mt Hood, you’d have a very hard time getting anywhere near that with freeze dried.

Snickers are like $.68/lb and mtn house are $2.55/lb, a pretty big difference, especially when you’re going to consume around 2.5 million calories (my mileage averaged 20 miles per day, but I started really slow because I did almost no training, but by the end was doing at least 30 miles per day in the extremely mountainous northern cascades). My consumption stayed around 8,000 calories per day the whole thing regardless of distance and elevation

For the pudding, just put on your gloves and massage the bag for like 5 minutes. Most of the streams are snowmelt on the pct (so temps close to freezing) and even the springs are still probably around 50 degrees. I wouldn’t use warm lake water for it (but that water tastes bad anyway)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Super Secret Homemade granola recipe from lakota/white earth NDN ex

1 cup rolled oats by weight
1 cup butter by weight
1/4 cup sugar or brown sugar/honey
1/4 cup sweetened condensed milk
1/8 cup(2table spoons) Molasses or Maple Syrup
optional
scoop of whey protein powder
1/8 cup bacon bits with the oatmeal
sprinkling seasoning or nutritional yeast on it when cool

melt butter in pot, add in condensed milk and sugar
add in oats/powder and stir until mixed
put into wax papered covered baking tray
level out granola
bake at 200F for 20min or for other elevations just pull it out immediately right when it starts to turn color
let cool to room temp, then freeze/put in fridge over night/until stiff enough to slice into 4 oz bars, wrap in wax paper and shove 4 in a mylar food bag

>Is it healthy?
fuck no
but its the most calorie dense thing next to eating lard/drinking oil
its 150 calories per oz, 600 a bar, it kicks a clif bars ass while being a fifth of the price (clif bars can fuck right off and walk a cliff after getting rid of carrot cake, theres only 2 edible flavors now)
>does it taste better than gas station food?
eh, at least its not pemmican
its inoffensive/non-tiring, easy to chew even in december and tastes good, you can shovel down 600 calories in mere seconds with 0 fucking around with starting a fire/jetboil, 2 bars gives you almost the same calories of an entire whole ass MRE, this is good after a day of hiking when you sometimes get weird "im not hungry" moods and can end up not eating at all, going to bed hungry is fine when its warm, but its a no no where its cold
>is it shelf stable
in MN where its -20F/-28C plus winchill even in the city, yeah
in a hot/humid backpack, idk???? itd definitely smell bad if its gone bad

posts.name: anon
posts.sub: The best agrochemicals to use on a small and large scale
posts.com:
In this thread I want to share the best agrichemicals that I use during my crops, they are all recommended by an agricultural engineer with a lot of experience. All agrichemicals fall into the organic category, but are still extremely effective.

deltamethrin (common trade name decis 10 from bayer)
It is extremely cheap, and effective, it kills all aphids, but it has a short effect of maximum 3 or 4 days, so it is recommended to apply it once a week, or once every two weeks. To apply it, you only have to use an atomizer or a backpack. It is always good to apply it as a preventative, and more or less you have to apply about 6% of the product in the water.
>copper oxychloride
It is a very powerful fungicide, which kills all fungi, preventing them from reproducing. It is good that when you prepare the soil you mix it with this to prevent fungus in the roots. You also have to spray it on the stem and leaves with a sprayer, the amounts don't really matter, but don't put too little either. They sell this product already prepared, but it sucks, it has to be powdered.
>diatomaceous earth
This is undoubtedly the best of all, since you have multiple uses, both for fertilizing, for killing ants (these are really difficult to kill), killing worms, mites, among others, it also serves as a fungicide for your ph. But they have to be careful not to apply it on the flowers as it can kill the bees.
>rice
This is not an agrochemical, and it does not kill anyone, but when the ants take it to their colony, they leave it stored and the rice starch generates a fungus that they end up eating, that fungus ends up killing them.

posts.name: anon
posts.com:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deltamethrin
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dicopper_chloride_trihydroxide
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diatomaceous_earth
Remember that if you are going to use them, always apply beforehand as a preventative. These agrochemicals literally kill everything but prevention is better than cure.
They are cheap, but many times they sell it in small bags as novelty inventions or something like that and they end up charging you 1000 times more than it is worth. I am from Argentina and I paid 2 usd for a kilo of pure diatom, surely it is worth much more there, but make sure by the color that it is pure, and that it is not mixed.

posts.name: anon
posts.com: I use diatomaceous earth for the fungus on my feet, and for the cockroaches in my house, and the truth is that it is very safe, so sure that if it is 100% pure you can put it in your mouth and nothing happens. In fact, diatoms are often used to deworm animals and even for human use in some foods.

posts.com: Gear's the least enjoyable aspect of the outdoors but, when you're sitting bored in the office waiting for your next trip, it's one of the few things you can do to scratch the itch a little bit (second behind route planning). That's why I try not to be too judgemental about gearheads. Personally, the only thing I really enjoy about gear is gradually figuring out over time what equipment is really essential, and what's just redundant. For instance, when I see someone with a cheap pair of sandals tied to the outside of their bag, I tend to think they've actually put the miles in. I used to think that hiking poles were vaguely ridiculous, but now I've done a long, remote multi-day hike (and, as such, necessarily carried a heavy pack a long way) I know how useful they are.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Big Scrub rainforest in coastal northern NSW is a great example of this. It was between 800,000-900,000ha (2.2million acres) of subtropical rainforest, now less than 1% of it remains. It was all cleared in the mid-late 1800s - the Robertson Land Act at the time stated that land leased from the government could only turn to freehold (i.e. privately owned) if it was completely clearfelled (among other conditions). The rich rainforest soil was great for agriculture and dairying, so essentially all of it was knocked down and burned within a period of 30 years. Lease conditions almost always did not allow for the sale of timber, so millions upon millions of superfeet of red cedar and white beech (some of the finest timber in the world) along with other softwoods and hardwood went wasted.

Picrel shows previous extent (yellow) against current extent (green) - the entire ecosystem is essentially functionally extinct

Quarries are actually really beautiful once they start becoming naturalized. And they provide important rocky and dry ecosytems that would otherwise be rare.

Shut up retard. No I don't think we should steam roll entire mountain tops and turn it into bare rock (+ acid mine pollution), but if it's already been done then there's a perfect opportunity to create a unique ecosystem there. There are many species that depend on the sort of early ecosystem that are created by disturbances such as wildfires or in this case strip mining. >>2529664
yeah over rocks and sharp areas having a wrap for the rope is gonna be a good idea and also gonna extend your rope life. get good gloves like the ones in the pic (petzl makes good climbing gear) make sure everything that gonna hold weight is rated for way more than you will ever use it for. yes the breaking hand usually will be at the back when rappelling. learn what a prussik and VT prussik knot's are and how to tie them. pulleys are gonna be used later as you get more knowledge and applied skill. fingerless gloves are a big no no always full finger (ropes will burn you so fast you cannot imagine) let me know if you have any other questions.

i wish i could teach you anon. rappelling is hella fun but i will say this. on low height drops its fine to do solo stuff bigger stuff you need a buddy. learn the difference between static and dynamic rope along with wet ropes. depends on what you do and where that will define what rope type you need.
>REI is a good source to just browse and get a rough idea.
>get a real harness trust me. you can get away with using tubular nylon for a bit but once you get a harness it feels so much better
>get a petzl william ball lock auto carabiner. it will make life easier
>avoid steel stuff unless its for anchors.
>avoid stuff that screws shut if you need to unscrew it on the rope or carry a multi-tool
>the pliers are a godsend.

we use simple static rope setups all the time at any angle up to 45 degrees in the fire service, including for hauling patients in stretchers. Falling on a static rope as long as there isn't much slack is super good enough

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523803
I would still get binoculars. Wider field of view, and compact rangefinders have small objective lenses. That means poorer low light performance. That matters if you are in dense woods with lots of shade/shadows, and dusk/dawn. Even binoculars with a small objective lens take that hit. You basically have to compromise in one way or another. These perform very well in low light, but they feel hefty at 1.31lbs(claimed) despite the compact size. Only way you save weight is by going with smaller objective lens, thus making them perform worse in low light.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525329
it's mostly subtleties once you get above a certain pricepoint/glass quality. things you won't notice until you have tried different tiers(and often back to back.) fine details are sharper in higher quality glass, as well as color accuracy. I think something like a Vortex Diamondback HD, Leupold BX-2, Carson RD, ect is where it really starts to "peak" and anything better is really a gain of inches at that point. that's why I can't spend $400 on binoculars when I'm extremely satisfied with my sub $200 pair. it's hard to imagine them being that much clearer, let alone worth the price. it depends on how much you actually use them, and what type of use.

Vortex Crossfire HD*

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525329

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525329
Reliability, as in the amount of use, banging around. etc they'll withstand before something breaks like the lens seals.

Resolution is a big one. Better bins are better able to resolve small objects. Matters if you are trying to count points on a durr, for example.

Color is more true on better bins, important for bird people.

Generally the mechanics are just nicer. The focus knob stays where you put it, as does the ocular adjustment.

You gotta use the things quite a bit to wring out the differences and that gets more true the more expensive the bins. I've had Swaro ELs and they are great, but I didn't really use them enough to justify the price difference between them and my trusty Zen Ray ED3s. Sold the ELs, they hold their value really well another good point for top end ones.

I'll use this thread: I saw this plastic US canteen in a thrift store here in Europakistan and I bought it for €2. It came with a nylon cover that doesn't snap on that well but I don't care. The canteen itself was spotless and it seemed good. Too bad the fucking thing leaks real bad and there was a flimsy gasket made of something inside the lid that I assume should be replaced.
I cannot post pictures but it's very thick plastic, a dark olive color. It says the usual FOR WATER ONLY DO NOT APPLY CANTEEN TO OPEN FLAME etc. etc. and on the bottom it says PE-HD (02 recycling code) US 1997
How do you Marines deal with a leaking canteen generally? You just get a new gasket? Throw the thing away?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531646
My US canteen doesn't use a gasket, so there's a few possibilities.
1. Remove the gasket, it's incorrect for your model and interfering with the actual seal.
Still leaks? Your model must need that gasket.
2a. Replace the gasket. A generic rubber o-ring from an auto parts or hardware store roughly 35-38mm should work
2b. Try a replacement cap. May cost as much as option 3.
2c. If you have the right tools, evenly remove a little material from the mating surface of the canteen rim.
3. Replace the canteen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531660
One I forgot, you could try wrapping the threads with PTFE or electrical tape. More of an improvised solution though, probably won't hold up to regular use.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531660
Thanks for the reply anon. So I've looked around and I've seen a video that showed how that the material often isn't flush at the seams, and that creates a gap from which the canteen leaks. It said that you should just sand that flush and so I did (correctly, I know how to do it), but it does still leak somewhat. I think I'll still need a gasket, so I guess I'll go to the hardware store tomorrow and get something around 38mm (I measured the thing that was inside at 1 1/2") and if it still leaks I'll chuck it. I have a Finnish one already which is excellent, but I liked the idea of having the US one as a backup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm from southern Appalachia, but I generally only carry firearms into the woods if it's muzzleloader or rifle season and I'll be within reasonable distance of a road, just in case a whitetail steps over a ridgeline. It happens. I've never seen any point in carrying a pistol, because the odds of needing to shoot a human being are lower than winning the Mega Millions (and everyone assumes everyone else is armed, anyway); the only realistic probability of an animal attacking a grown man in these parts is the classic stumbling between a black bear and its cubs scenario. Climbing into my car to drive to the nearest town is at least 100x riskier than going into the woods unstrapped. If we start to develop a noticeable feral hog problem or something along those lines, I might change my mind.

I do keep at least a pistol in my vehicle and sometimes on my person whenever I'm traveling to a city with >100,000k population, because that's where you're far more likely to run into dangerous animals. It ain't the woods, that's for sure.

As for improvised weapons that are actually tools and not proper weapons (despite what Airstrip One citizens seem to believe), I always carry a folding knife, optionally a skinning knife or boning knife, and I may carry the very same Estwing hatchet (which is top-tier) shown in the OP's pic when hiking/camping.

posts.sub: Bow drill help and Fire thread
posts.com: What am I doing wrong here? I have been making a lot of hot dust and smoke but no embers “jumping” out as I’ve seen and heard it described. One spindle is oak and the other is cyprus, the board (?) is a palm branch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533308
Wish I could help, I have only tried it a few times with similar results to yours. I just assumed the wood I was using for the fire board wasn't the best suited for the task. Just smoke and dust and never an ember.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Use a softer wood for the spindle and make sure everything is completely dry.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Also, cut the "v" notch about 2/3 of the way into the hole after you see some carbon dust being made. If you're not creating a bunch of black dust in the hole, your fire board and spindle woods are wrong.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533308
Came across this video yesterday, it's pretty good.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YKJksRIBzNc

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Also, embers won't jump out. The carbon dust will fall through the v notch and make a little pile. If everything is good you need to increase drill speed and pressure until the top of the carbon pile gets a little glowing ember on top. You should see a lot of smoke just before this happens.

>>2531884

Main hard skills are probably excel, sql, and a bi tool (power bi, tableau, or looker)
You should also learn some basic domain areas- like a functional area in a company (marketing or finance or hr etc)
So learn some skills, make a portfolio, apply to junior analyst roles.
Lots of kinds of analysts are specialists in domains, ie a finance analyst needs to know more finance stuff. Data analysts tend to know lots of technical data stuff like relational modeling and be conversant in data science concepts. Business analysts do cost benefit analysis on business topics. Lmk if you have more questions

actually sometimes acrylic or nylon are added on purpose to make the garment less stretchy.
my thoughts on blends:
if its done as an intentional design decision, up to +0.5 tier
if its done to cut costs, up to -0.5 tier
and those blends where its like 30%/30%/30%/10% of various animal fibers, no idea how to score those, really depends.

if anyone's used all the various sheep/lamb's wools out there i'd like to hear how you rank them too.
i also think i should bump cotton up to niche tier. it gets a bad rap and it partially deserves it, but it has its niche: pretty much every other fiber with high durability has gross hand feeling, & its one of the only durable fibers that doesn't melt easy. even with all the choices i have in my gear closet: i often reach for a cotton flannel when i'm day hiking in the mountains in the fall on a good weather forecast. or if i'm doing anything high abrasion on my gear like swinging an axe or running a chainsaw all day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518208

>Cotton base layer

Death sentence. Cotton absorbs moisturize which results in the loss of any thermal properties. All of your sweat will adhere to your skin as dampness and make you colder. This can be lethal if all that dampness starts to freeze. Wool fibers also absorb sweat but they breathe better and keep their thermal properties when damp.

To quote the Norwegian Armed Forces winter clothing literature:

>On the negative side, cotton is a fibre that easily absorbs moisture and requires
impregnation in order to withstand the damp. Cotton absorbs and accumulates
moisture, which results in its insulating properties being lost even with a small
degree of damp. When a cotton garment is wet it becomes heavy and takes a
relatively long time to dry.

Merino is so popular because the fibers are smooth enough to be comfortable in itch-prone areas. I've heard alpaca wool has ever smoother fibers but have no experience with it and I don't think it's common.

So try merino wool as your directly-against-the-skin base layer. If that's still itchy, then wear synthetic. Anything but cotton.

some people don't have a choice m8, although you're right that it helps to buy better wool.

If ya'll want a protip, if you find that you have skin sensitivity plus sensitivity to light/sound (e.g. you feel excessively touchy and uncomfortable in supermarkets or music stores that tend to be bright and noisy), it might be neurological. Can't remember what it's called, but your brain is getting overloaded with hyper-stimulus from normal stimuli. It's related to ADHD/OCD/the rest of it and exists on a spectrum, ie. you can be very hyper-sensitive or you can be mildly hyper-sensitive under certain conditions.

The bad thing is you can't cure it. The good thing is you can easily treat the primary symptom (everything feels so itchy/bright/noisy/etc, but so much more than "makes sense" when you think about the lights or the sounds in isolation, and yet it's impossible to ignore): When you get up in the morning, gently rub your body all over with something mildly abrasive like a sponge or a soft brush and use a medium or stiff brush on your hair. Your nails will work but it helps to use a tool of some kind. You'll eventually feel oddly relaxed, like you got out of the bath. Your hyper-stimulus symptoms will be lessened for the rest of the day. Just don't overdo it, because you can go too far and irritate the skin/other obvious outcomes.

This tip does not help people who do not have hyper-sensitivity issues. If you're just a wimp then it cannot help. The cure for being a wimp is to progressively toughen up by increasing challenges, just like with building strength or endurance. Your mind is a muscle and can be trained and manipulated like any other part of the body. It might help to know that the majority of physiological changes (e.g. RBC count, cold sensitivity, depressant dependency, etc) will noticeably improve after 2-4 weeks of training. Stick out any training routine for one month before saying "what I'm doing doesn't seem to work."

>>2533139
Anyone claiming they have a 4 season tent just fell for a marketing gimmick. Generally, a “winter tent” is one that can stand up to high winds and heavy snow loads. A “3 season” tent can still handle a fair amount of snow and wind, just not nearly as much.
>we’ll why not just use a winter tent all year?
Condensation is a major issue, as these tents aren’t designed to breathe. Warm moisture from your breath gather and condense on the cool tent walls and on your sleeping bag, and you’ll end up damp. It does t happen in the appropriate environment because the relative humidity is already mega low so anything you exhale is negligible. These tents are also very heavy and very expensive.

>>2533139
No, the main benefits to a 4 season is not just materials that they are generally more wind and moisture resistant but also that they are designed to handle high wind and snow loads. They may also put focus on being able to set up the fly first to provide shelter faster.

Any good 3 season double wall tent is going to handle most rain just fine. The main tent body might be mesh but the rain fly is what is actually protects from the rain. It is possible in prolonged rain for that material to saturate but that doesn't mean it just rolls right through. For what it's worth, the presence of a full mesh body vs a partially nylon and mesh body is not what differentiates a 3 season from a 4 season. I don't even like those terms much because a '4 season' tent is not needed to camp in the cold.

>>2533175
There is always a chance of condensation because the person or persons inside exhale moist, warm air. More airflow helps so it's less common with mesh bodies but still possible. In below freezing weather its normal to have frost in the interior collect on the tent interior from your breath in the morning.

posts.com: What are the actual benefits of a hammock over an ultralight tent?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529428
>comfort
This is an obvious one. No matter how thick your pad is, it will never be as comfy as an appropriately sized and correctly hung hammock.

>ventilation/condensation
It’s a major issue in the south east, and hammocks are the most ventilated shelter option. The comparison to single wall tents isn’t even close.

>site selection is easier
On a macro scale, you can choose a general area and be guaranteed to find at least an ok hammock spot (if you’re in a forest, obviously). Generally that’s done to be on the leeward side of a hill, or further from a water source, or in a less-traveled area. In a micro sense, there are fewer worries about rocks, sticks, vegetation, or roots. A slight angle to the ground doesn’t matter. Puddles aren’t a major concern. You’ll never set up only to realize there’s a weird lump under your hip.

>slight versatility
I can keep my tarp in it’s skins if I’m certain there won’t be any rain, pull back just half of it for privacy, leave up one side in “porch mode,” or really hunker down in storm mode. A single walled tent is set up one way.

>utility
A hammock tarp is fairly large, providing much more useable space if there’s rain. It’s only a slight advantage, as most decent tents already have enough space under the vestibule. A hammock also doubles as a chair, but it’s not like you can just plop it down wherever (but it’s still a place to sit).

>not stuck in a dog house while it’s raining
Self explanatory. I’ll be in a hammock, sitting sideways, swaying lightly with my hammock in porch mode while I listen to the rain pattering lightly against my tarp. Peak comfy.

>cooler, as in less hot
This really only applies to the Deep South, where summer nighttime temps can make sleeping in a tent much less enjoyable. The convective heat loss in a hammock is a net positive.

>great for old people
Old folks have trouble sleeping on really hard surfaces, and we won’t be “young” forever.

>trend
Trends don’t fade away. I think you meant “fad,” but were inadvertently correct; people switching to hammocks from tents is indeed a trend.

It’s hard to say when it started, but it was definitely more than 10 years ago. I know Dutch (from Dutchware) hiked the AT with a hammock in 2003, and it was a sort of novelty at the time. But his company has been around probably since 2008, and he started selling hammock bodies in 2011 or 2012 (I still have a netless Poly-D).

The reason it even became a thing is because of the internet. For a large part of the US, a hammock has a lot of benefits. But tents are ubiquitous. People didn’t really think to use a hammock until they saw other people doing it online.

It’s not going to just fade away, but it won’t completely replace tents either.

>Ventilation
I will actually give this to all forms of tarp camping. Although there's a skill and variability to it being able to adjust how close the tarp is to the ground, how closed off it is, etc. really allows you to dial it in. In the
>Cooler
factor as well, you can get more air flow or with a large enough tarp can create a really nice wind shield.
>Versatility
As above, can definitely tailor the shelter a bit more. Not as much as tarp only but close.
>Site selection
I will give this a yes but it is dependent on your area. If you camp more desert, rocky alpine, meadowlands you may have more issues finding appropriate hang spots.
>Rain
On one hand I've had gear get a little damp with splash, but on the other I have slept through inches of rain without a bother.

I will give tents credit in that the lack of flexibility is sometimes a boon. It only goes up one way and if you're comfy on the ground it's a lot more 'brain off do camp task' after a long day. It took many trips to dial in my hammock camping to a point where it is both fast and consistent.

Most good hammocks come with an attached bugnet. They zip on to one edge of the hammock, and are suspended above you by the hammocks structural ridge line. When not in use they can be bundled up and tied in neatly to the sewn edge. Some can zip completely off, but that’s not very common. Mosquitoes can easily bite through a hammock but not though an underquilt.

Another option is a full coverage net like the one in this pic I’ve posted a few dozen times. It’s several ounces heavier than a zip on net but can be used in the warmer months without an underquilt. Most have poorly designed, oddly shaped zippers, so you really have to shop around for one.

>>2529827
Sure if you are full blown moron maybe stick with AAs. If you can't possibly think ahead enough to bring a spare battery sure.

But ultimately what matters is the amount of power stored in the battery and how it can deliver it. A premium AA delivers 1.5v and stores about 2200 milliamphours. An 18650, for example. delivers 3.7v and stores 3500 milliamphours.

This means 1 18650 has the energy of a bit more than 3 AAs. If you care about high drain applications like super bright ass lights a AA maxes out at 2 amps while the best 18650s will do 35 amps.

So you can get a whole pile more light (more than 3x) from a full 18650 than you can a AA. If you do use that much light in a single trip they can all be recharged, some even have built in USB ports so you don't need a separate charger. Of course you can also get lights with built in chargers, either USB ports or sealed magnetic contacts.

And this is just 18650s. The difference against 26650s are even bigger.

Only a fucking moron would think being able to buy a AA in a gas station is a meaningful advantage.
